content:
Posted: February 27
												It's as step up from theHunter: Classic in some areas and a step back in others, however it's a good platform to build on like they did with Classic.Pros: - Updated graphics, some of the best scenery you will see in any game. - Hunting pressure, new mechanic to make it difficult to hunt in areas you've already hunted.- Improved animal behaviors. Animals will give warning calls, mating calls, and can be found in large heards.  There was also the addition of "need zones" that you can discover such as sleeping zones, drinking and feeding zones where you can find specific species at certain hours of the day.- Night hunting, with the help of a headlamp. - CoTW replaces a membership pay model of Classic with a RPG system that makes you gradually unlock new weapons and equipment through XP, also has a pretty neat skills/perks system that really adds some flavor to hunting. Cons: - Lacks the diversity of theHunter: Classic. Only 2 hunting reserves at the time of launch, a handful of weapons and a pretty small roster of game to hunt. - Scoring system seems wonky, not a huge fan of the "consecutive harvests" idea. The game awards senseless killing and not being patient and selective like it should be. - Small features like trophy shots and trophy galleries not available at this time. Guessing in the future? Not sure why something like this would be cut from the game.- Performance issues, some people complaining about crashes/bugs. Latest patch addressed some issues though.-  No mobile tree stands, or tents. You have to discover outposts around the map and use them to fast travel.

												Contrary to what my profile shows, I have more than 10 hours experience to back up my opinion of this game. I am not ashamed to admit that I bought this game today, and that I trialed it with an illegal copy of the game. Point is I've bought it now and at the time of writing this have tested it on version 1.11. I'm not even one to play many FPS games, let a alone an FPS game that simlulates hunting and as such requires you to be patient while moving veryyyyy slowly and cautiously so that you do not disturb your prey.  This is something new for me as a gamer who needs relatively paced gameplay with action at least every now and then. I was drawn in by this game's graphics presentation and this ultimately led me to try out the game. To my surprise, the gameplay also started to appeal to me after getting the hang of it and now I am convinced that this game deserves a try. If you like survival type games, rather come to this with a fresh perspective and you may enjoy theHunter for what it is and not for what it isn't. Also, there are several glitches that I have encountered but none were too detractive of the whole experience. My only gripe with this game so far is the inventory management system, which seems to bug out a lot depending on whether or not I am using KB/M or a controller at any given time. Devs, you have surpassed my expectations of this game, please fix these issues and more people will come to realise the potential of what you have made.

content:
Posted: February 28
												I like this game.  But let me start with the cons:Slowest walking simulator ever made.  They need to increase run speed by about 30%,  as, when you're traveling at running speed, you generally don't care if there is prey nearby that will run.  You're just trying to get where you're going.  And as there are no real "save" points, you always spawn at the last outpost you were at.  It can take forever to get from one place to another and it just takes tooooo lonnnng.   Maybe make it so you don't need to jump to get over fist-sized rocks when climbing uphill, while you're at it.  I shot a moose, which glitched out- shot it again, then again, at point blank, then it rand at lightspeed away into the distance.  F that moose.  At one point I jumped near a small waist-height tree and immediately died.  Game is buggier than a termite mound.  I wish you could save at any point, and start where you left off, or maybe have it autosave every 10-15 minutes in case the game crahes, instead of at your last outpost.  They're miles apart, and take forever to get back to, so if you do die jumping near a tiny tree, you're going to cry when you respawn miles away.Pros:Apex engine is beautiful.  If you have the gpu/cpu to rock this at ultra, it's stunning.  Audio is gorgeous as well,  it puts you right into it's world with all of the ambience you'd expect from a living forest.  Tracking and hunting remind me of Witcher 3 without all the Noonwraiths.  I've only been playing the Pacific NW-ish map, and I really like the mission-giving walkie-talkie guy.  It reminds me of firewatch, but not as linear, with no plot.   This is a great game to play when you're tired of getting smashed in the face in For Honor or need a break from anything competitive or serious.  It's calming, slow, and patient.  I have an i5 4670 and an R9 290, and can play this at 1440p with most settings at ultra but a few turned down.  Apex engine is beautiful - but demanding.  Another thing I wish they'd fix is the cost of items.  The progression system needs skin unlocks or something to motivate you while you save 30000 for that one rifle.  Plus skins are cool!  People love skins!Overall, there's a LOT to dislike, but TH:COTW still has somehow won me over.  There's a lot of heart in this game.  And a lot of shooting things in the heart, I suppose.  This will remain in my rotation as the game I play to chill after a stressful day.  Overall, recommended if you're looking for something different and don't mind early access (because that's what this really is, feels-wise).  If you have the cash, it's a fun diversion.  They've been steadily ironing out the bugs, and I look forward to future updates.

content:
Posted: February 27
												It's as step up from theHunter: Classic in some areas and a step back in others, however it's a good platform to build on like they did with Classic.Pros: - Updated graphics, some of the best scenery you will see in any game. - Hunting pressure, new mechanic to make it difficult to hunt in areas you've already hunted.- Improved animal behaviors. Animals will give warning calls, mating calls, and can be found in large heards.  There was also the addition of "need zones" that you can discover such as sleeping zones, drinking and feeding zones where you can find specific species at certain hours of the day.- Night hunting, with the help of a headlamp. - CoTW replaces a membership pay model of Classic with a RPG system that makes you gradually unlock new weapons and equipment through XP, also has a pretty neat skills/perks system that really adds some flavor to hunting. Cons: - Lacks the diversity of theHunter: Classic. Only 2 hunting reserves at the time of launch, a handful of weapons and a pretty small roster of game to hunt. - Scoring system seems wonky, not a huge fan of the "consecutive harvests" idea. The game awards senseless killing and not being patient and selective like it should be. - Small features like trophy shots and trophy galleries not available at this time. Guessing in the future? Not sure why something like this would be cut from the game.- Performance issues, some people complaining about crashes/bugs. Latest patch addressed some issues though.-  No mobile tree stands, or tents. You have to discover outposts around the map and use them to fast travel.

Also don't listen to any of the asses complaining about this game, they don't have a clue what they are talking about. content:
Posted: March 1
												This review is for solo play only, I haven't tried online play yet.  The game feels like early access (particularly because of the UI being unresponsive at times) but it is in a highly playable state at the moment. I've spent 5 hours so far, and I've enjoyed the title. Other than the UI occaisonally taking two clicks instead of one I've only seen one bug, A deer was stuck in a tree trying to run away. Not exactly the end of the world, as you see similar pathing errors pop up in Bethesda games. The environment is very well rendered, effects like tall grass getting stomped down as you walk through a field were a nice touch. Probably one of the most relaxing games involving shooting I've ever played. Provided support and development continues, this is well worth picking up. Particularly if you enjoyed the original 'TheHunter' but were put off by microtransactions. Wait if you're worried about the title being dropped, otherwise give it a go.

												Haven't play much of it yet so not a really reliable review.The game looks and feels great as far as a hunting game goes. Compared to other hunting games that are all arcade point and shoot, this game is as close to real hunting that most gamers will get to. Having an open world where you can go wherever you want or shoot whatever you want is really all most people ask for in a hunting game. A few things I have noticed:-Deer dont seem to walk and act like deer, although they are still huntable.-The Sound effects are awful. Like minecraft sound awful. In a game where you are trying to sneak up on a deer, the slowest footstep I can manage sounds like Im kicking gravel down the driveway.A few things the game needs:-FISHING!!! The number of ponds and lakes that look perfect for fishing is immense. Add fishing to this game and why would I ever play another game?-More animals. Aside from basic deer, moose, elk and bear you can hunt foxes and coyotes. Also Buffalo. I noticed a distict lack of bird hunting. Ambient birds are loud and annoying and deserve to be shot.-Polish. The game is good, really good. but there are things here and there that need shining. If the devs are still updating we can only hope the game gets better.Don't let anyone talk you out of this game because of glitches or bugs or because it's hard to kill or track. Hunting isn't easy IRL.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												We know why you are here. Lets just get this out of the way right now. This has some of the most beautiful environments I've ever seen in a game. If you love the outdoors as much as I, then you where probably equally pained throughout the Elder Scroll's laughable attempts at wilderness. Skyrim's best just wasn't real enough for me. It all looked... unnatural, as if someone who had never been outdoors looked at pictures. The great outdoors got that name for a reason. This game understands. Freaking. Gorgeous. I play on Ultra with a measly 8gigs of Ram, GTX 970 and an i5 6400. It runs great. If the optimization is buggy, I havn't noticed.Next up, if you like hunting games, your options are fairly limited. The Hunter Classic, Cabela's Hunts, maybe Hunting Unlimited if you can stomach the ancient graphics and mechanics. Now The Hunter Classic is a favorite of mine, despite my low play time, it rocked. I'm currently getting into Bowhunting IRL, and when I play these types of games, I'm looking at Bows only. Make of that what you will.The Hunter Classic had a variety of weapons, animals, and reserves. In comparison CotW, is pretty underwhelming. TWO BOW TYPES!? WHAT IS THIS HERESY!? Not even a recurve, or a longbow, or more compound... just a beginner compound and a high end. A real shame, as I really like variety and the challenge that a recurve provides. Same with Shotguns, hope you weren't looking for a large variety here. Seems the devs liked rifles more, and it reflects in the quests, some require super long range shots... which rules out bows and shotties. You get a paltry two reserves.... but they are pretty dang massive. I'd say they are equal to ... the alaskan one from the Hunter Classic in size. Lots of little things to find, and things to do. Shed Hunting, Feed ground spotting, camp finding, dozens of quests, Animal variety is ... fairly small in comparison to the hunter classic. I don't think the game has Grizzly, Wolves, or some of the varieties of Elk and Deer. I also didn't notice ANY waterfowl, or turkey. Although the ambient animals are significantly improved. Lots more birds, rabbits, squirrels ( I think that's what it was.. scared the alcohol right out of me.)So what about the important stuff? The actual hunting? Its superb. When it works. The game seems to have alot more wildlife than the Hunter Classic, so you are in the thick of it pretty much every step. Hit that caller and watch a group of four just wander in. Its probably not realistic, but it gets you into the hunt much quicker. ...now if you don't have any experience with hunting games, you probably will make the mistake of thinking that the .243 you start with is somehow effective at hunting.You would be wrong.The .243 modeled in this game and the Hunter Classic is a pea-shooter, that probably shouldn't be allowed on Deer, I have no experience with .243 in real life, but if you don't make a perfect shot, expect that deer to run for quite a ways. Its a beginner gun, do not expect them to drop with one shot unless you hit the sweet spot behind the front legs kinda near the knee. God help you if you take pot shots at a bear... like I did. 4-6 shots to put down a charging bear is not pretty. You ideally want to upgrade pretty much immediately. Men use bows, as our anscestors did. Real Men use Recurves as god intended, but the developers are clearly not as concerned as I. Point is, the beginner rifle will give you a bad impression if you are new to hunting. Stick with it. ... then get a bow. ;) Nothin like taking that perfect bow shot up close, and watching that buck drop....oh and this might as well be a beta for how buggy it is. I have numerous screenshots in my 3 hours of play of animals getting stuck on vegetation. Really the only bug I've found. If an incredibly annoying one. You spook an animal it will sometimes just fly right into a bush or tree and get stuck. The Hunter Classic had some great bug fixing, so I'm hoping this gets fixed. We shall see. Oh and the tutorial is absolutely terrible. If you are new too hunting, please for the love of god youtube some videos. Animals are smart. You have to be to get them. Calls, Stalking, Tree Stands, and an incredible amount of patience apply here.FINAL VERDICT TOO LONG DIDN'T READ: Lack of weapons. Lack of Reserves. Fantastic game, gorgeous environments, pretty buggy, so unless you LOVE to hunt (Like me.) I would wait for a sale. That being said, I HIGHLY reccomend this game if you are into the hunt.

content:
Posted: March 1
												This game is worth the $30 and it is a great improvement over the last game.Pros:-No microtransaction (everything can be unlocked relatively easily, to those saying it takes ages you just have to stop scaring away everything you are about to shoot, I've unlocked 2 new rifles in 10 hours of gameplay)-Beautiful graphics (the optimisation however isn't the best for example having too many points marked on the GPS can cause lag when the GPS is open)-Easily the most realistic hunting sim (weapon ballistics, correct hitboxes for each animal)-Multiplayer is very easy to setup and is p2p (just invite your friend to your game and they'll be able to join)-Very nice sounds-Very large map and nicely decoratedCons:-Animals sometimes stand in place (haven't encountered this since patch though)-Average optimisation-Some animals for example rabbits and birds can be killed but you cannot harvest their bodies-You make way more noise than you should (having a walk button that makes you slower and quiter could solve this)-Sometimes the tracks are pointing in the wrong direction-Bears attacking you is a bit glitchy-Some form of campaign/storyline which is nice however they're basically just quests to go do thingsThings you should know before buying:-Only 14 different weapons without around 2-3 ammo types for each-This is a very slow paced game so you'll probably find yourself getting frustrated if you're sprinting around looking for animals to shoot-Map is very large and there isn't any vehicles however when you claim an outpost you can fast travel between them-Your shots can ricochet off animals and you'll probably get mad and think it is a bug like I did the first time it happened-It helps to know how to hunt in real life-Knowing where to aim is key-Ballistic system-RPG like leveling up and skill system however they don't make much of a difference-High end system is probably needed-This game has controller supportSo yes I recommend this game at it's current price of $30 with no microtransactions

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26
												**DISCLAIMER** This is NOT going to be a serious, well structure review so if that is something you are looking for then you are better off scrolling on.Call of the wild is my first real hunter game I've gotten into, I dabbled in the free to play version but once you realise how much of a sting all the micro-transations are then it can be an instant turn off for loads of people, including myself. But then this beauty comes along, a one time payment, everything in the game is unlocked and available to use (Outside of the ingame currency earned) and there is room for DLC in the future. I really hope they don't take the mick with it though.Gameplay wise I find it very pleasing, tailing and calling in prey to be shot is really satisfying, especially if the kill is a beauty. Patience is a virtue in this game thats for sure.Graphically it is stunning, you can check my profile for some of the screen shots but this game really has some stunning moments in the game, all made available to capture through the ingame camera (for added feels). If it isn't the wildlife that grabs your attention it is the landscape!A few bugs I've noticed so far is sometimes the hitscan seems way off, I'll aim for the vital organs but when I claim the trophy ive shot right up the poop shaute.. Another is that the callers seem to bug and wont go off when used. I'm unsure if this is an audio thing or if it actually doesn't work in game when the item is used. Lastly I've had a really rare bug where I can't toggle to other eequipment. It isn't holdstered and the symbol in the bottom right will change but the character won't take out the respective equipment nor is it able to be used.Overall I love this game, and I am sure to have many more hours! As mentioned I just hope DLC isn't something that takes the mick over time.. Last thing steam needs is another Train Simulator DLC mockery!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												Currently at 20 hours of gampelay in this and I can understand why the game is recieving mixed reviews.First off: Bugs. Yes there are bugs. The game was JUST released and by a developer who is small compared to other developers. Give them time. They actively listing to the community and review what is said. Bugs will be fixed, have patience.Some feel this game should be marked as early access. I personally disagree, for what it has it feels like a functional game, it just needs some patches/hotfixes. It is a full working game for the most part.The graphics are absolutely stunning, even on the lowest setting.If you've played The Hunter (Classic) you know what to expect, tracking, tracking, more tracking and finally the kill shot. This plays similar but the maps are MUCH larger. Hirschfelden is at least 6 times larger (IMO), the classic map itself is contained in the North East to give you an idea of size.It has a decent amount of weapons, good selection of rifles, handguns, shotguns, and bows. All the necessary callers/scents for the current animals, and they will be adding more as they expand their reserves, why wouldn't they? Look at how many animals and reserves they have in Classic.If you've never played The Hunter (Classic), this is not like other first person shooters, though I hope that would be obvious enough to not have to say. Keeping in mind that the Dev's will be releasing more content, and If I remember correctly the price should stay at ~$30, compare the average cost for the Classic game: weapons, outfits, membership fees, all the reserves and animals possible to hunt. You'd be talking potentially upwards of $60 if not even more (I've sunk more than I care to admit into that game and I still love it). $30 is NOT a lot compared to that, and it's on a more modern engine with planned content being made.For weapons each rifle and pistol comes with two different ammunition types that, I feel, are a little too similar right now. Shotguns still have three types of rounds.Animals now have different classes that are used for them (0-4 currently). 0 being Coyotes and Foxs, 4 being bears and bison. Weapons have a specific class type that can be used for any animal of the same class or higher (not effeciently), if you use a higher class weapon against a lower class animal it will ruin the integrity, causing lower payout and score (potentially score).Bows on the other hand have 3 ammo types, where each ammo type is a different class. I find that interesting because it makes it more versitile. Bows now take some getting used to due to the now random arrow off-set that can happen (The in-game dev's themselves state it is NOT the aim wobble but a different calculation) but is still a VERY powerfull weapon.All in all, I'd say $30 is definitely a very fair price for the game, in it's current status and obviously as more content gets released.EDIT: Forgot to add: NIGHTTIME HUNTING! I totally forgot about this. The game includes a FULL night/day cycle and you have a headlamp that is used to find tracks at night. This actually provides a bit more challenge because you can only see the tracks one of two ways: Stumbling over it or looking around with the headlamp on. I love the increased difficulty of this because it makes it more fun in my opinion. Couple that with the weather cycle that was heavily improved on compared to Classic (wind can affect your scent direction and distance, but also make you harder to hear), Fog makes you more difficult to see, and Rain can also affect how difficult you are to hear.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game certainly has some strong qualities. Great graphics. Excellent lighting effects, weather effects etc.Really large map. Nice weapons and accessories.Tracking system is not overcomplicated.But it also has some weak qualities. No vehicles on a ridiculously large map. You have to walk everywhere. All of the time. It's so boring sometimes when you just want to go from point A to point B.The level progression is insanely slow, to the point where it can take days to get a new weapon. No way to pause the game, literally, none. You can't rest without paying the money you earned from hunting. That's the dumbest thing I've ever seen in a video game. In the current state I do not recommend this game. It is good for just relaxing instead of going fast paced like in most games, but other than that it needs some serious improvements in those areas.EDIT: Still giving it a go. I just went up a tower to survey the land, with the intent on finding the nearest hunting camp afterwards. Fell off the tower, now I have to walk nearly 2KM to get to the new camp. All because there are nowhere near enough fast travel points. This is the main problem with this game. I hope things get better because once a few of these issues are fixed this could be one of the best games ever.

content:
Posted: March 20
												I really would like to give this game a good review. It's obviously made by professionals, and has a lot of potential. Unfortunately, it's just not possible to recommend someone spend $30 on this. There are too many bugs, and they're not just minor nuisances. It's irritating when the game starts up and the mouse cursor isn't locked to the screen, or you're just given the view from a player camera frozen in the air and you have to restart. I don't like it when you place a waypoint and it acts strangely, or the screen of your smart device disappears, or when you have to click a menu element five times to get it to respond. But when animals don't react to your presence, or when you shoot them and they freeze in place like statues that soak up your bullets, there's just no point in playing. The game's just broken, and you shouldn't buy something that's broken. Bugs aside, the only complaint I have is that the game is trying to be as realistic as possible, but the geometry of the terrain is just generic video game terrain that doesn't even remotely resemble reality. They could salvage the game at some point, but right now, don't buy it.Update:I originally posted this review after about 4 hours of play, and I had already encountered all of those bugs. I stuck with it, mostly to have something to do while I listen to podcasts, and the bugs just keep coming. No part of this game isn't broken. Every UI element, every interaction, every game mechanic is flat-out broken. It would be one thing if this game was in early access, but selling this a finished product is a stretch, if not downright deceptive. If they honestly believe this is a finished product, then they must not be anticipating doing the amount of work it would take to just be able to say it's not broken. That is worrisome.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												+10 hours since release and im enjoying the game so far. I havent tried the multiplayer yet so this is going to be mostly a single player focused review. For starters the game launched pretty sloppy for many, including my self, and many of the issues are still prevelent such as graphical glitches, crashes, and AI issues, sound issues. Since launch the game has felt like a unpolished beta rushed to meet a release deadline.The game over all plays pretty well for those who are a fan of The Hunter and already know what to expect. For new comers to the series It might be the only start to The Hunter they can enjoy since Classic has more of a F2P/P2W business model behind it and isnt very welcoming to new players since they are locked out of 95% of the great content in the game. If you are new to the series i would recommend picking this game up over playing classic first, if you are not a new commer to the The Hunter you might find this game a tad bit lacking in terms of equipment and features (dogs, tents, stands, tripods, scents, callers, birds, ducks, geese, blinds) so it wont fill those voids if you've enjoyed +100 hours with those features in your hunts. The game offers two reserves to hunt on and a wide array of equipment to use and animals to track and spot, Every animnal you harvest is awarded with XP and cash based on the difficulty of the animal, the weapon used and the shot placement and whether or not the animal died instantly or bled out over time. New features to the game are the new stealth mechanic, sight and sound now play an important factor as well as smell, the noob friendly meters on the HUD will show you how visible or how noisy you are in the environment, i found that the controller utilized these features better than traditional K/M. Progression in The Hunter is very different from other games and very time consuming, and given the unpredictiblity of many animals the game does not reward simple tasks and you will find yourself grinding or side tracked many times. A few new features to the game are "need zones", areas where animals migrate or congregate based on there needs at that specific time of day. NIght time hunting is also a new feature, hunting at night is alot more challenging than during the day you will find yourself wandering the game world following tracks since animals are usually quieter during the night. The new features in CofW are refreshing and a good reason to pick the game up if you like simulation or hunting games. Over all the core elements play well.  The game ran fine on a single Zotac GTX 980 on ultra for the most part with a Gsync display and Vsync turned on for many hours on end so its not a very demanding game if youve still got an older gen card in your machine. I have yet to test the game in SLi but for the most part it runs well without SLi.In review, The Hunter CotW is essentialy a bare bones experience of The hunter classic with an updated game engine and graphics and some unique gameplay features. I can see this game being polished and packaged really well in the future with a handful of updates and DLCs but for now you will only be getting a fraction of what The Hunter Classic has to offer currently.Graphics: 8/10Gameplay:7/10Features:7/10Content:6/10Over all: 7/10A solid game for sim lovers and hunters alike.

content:
Posted: March 23
												TL:DR - Its the most beautiful game you will ever see. The screenshots barely do it justice. Gameplay is pretty good, just what you'd expect from a hunting game. Multiplayer is very fun and easy to get into.-------------------------------------------Hands down, without question, THE MOST jaw-droppingly gorgeous game I have ever played. Turn your graphics up, your sound up, headphones on and just close your eyes. Its amazing. I moved out from the shadow of a tree into the sunlight and I would swear to you, I felt my arm get warm. THAT'S what kind of immersion this game delivers. You are going to walk around, ALOT. But once you come across the huts, you can resupply and fast travel between any you've unlocked. Hunting feels rewarding and frustrating at the same time. You need to move slowly, keeping an eye on your sound levels, but its only natural to want to "hurry up" and catch your prey. I found that after hearing an animal call out, it was easier to take up a good position, use my caller and wait for it to come to me. Multiplayer is very easy to get into and the fact that its up to 8 player co-op is pretty awesome. You can team up or go your own seperate ways and hunt "alone." You can even issue challenges and compete against one another. The mechanics themselves can be a big grindy. You need to make sure you try your best to take down your target with one hit so that it goes down quick and clean. You're pay for the kill will change depending on those parameters. It definitely takes awhile to unlock the weapons but everything is available ingame, no micro transactions.Shooting feels pretty good. Once you kill your animal and track it down (if you dont kill it outright) you can actually see where the bullet entered, what body parts it hit etc etc. Overall, I recommend it. Its absolutely gorgeous, 9/10

content:
Posted: February 22
												Waited a long time for this game and fortunately it turned out to be everything I hoped it would be. There are some bugs and issues, but none have been in any way gamebreaking for me. The important stuff works.So here's some of the things that are great:- The visuals and sounds are gorgeous in every way and there's nice variety in locations.- The chase gives you the same kind of thrills as when you go hunting for real.- Tracking is done properly and is quite enjoyable.- Player movement and gunplay is spot on.- The statistics info on the harvested animal is done properly.Some small things that still need some improvement:- The menu and keybinds have some problems- Gear needs a lot more variety, since now there's only a fraction of the items from the original. But I guess that's the DLC plan...- Sneaking feels a bit dodgy and the vagueness of the movement sound UI doesn't help. Makes it a lot more difficult to track wounded animals.- The animal AI sometimes does funny things like gets stuck on things.- Freaked out wounded animals run around way too fast compared to the real thing.- It feels like the bleeding mechanic also needs a bit of tweaking. If you miss all the critical target hitboxes, the animal always bleeds at the "Very low" bleed rate, even with clear head- or gut shots. Also, wounds bleed more if you run, so running speed should affect the bleed rate.- I would prefer vehicles (or a horse) over fast travel any day.Conclusion: A very enjoyable hunting game and I expect it only to get better.

content:
Posted: February 20
												First off, to explain why I recommend this game:If you have been waiting for a hunting game to relive the old times like back in Deer Hunter 2005, this may just be it. However, if you are invested in theHunter Classic and have played that, you may want to stick with that for a while.As many have said, this game feels like a Beta title. The bugs are there, and while I haven't had anything game-breaking, they are still there. First, this game is beautiful. Just walking around, taking in the sights is a great experience that I find extremely relaxing.But, I have a few small gripes with the game in my playtime so far. For one, I feel like the animal AI is strange. The deer move at such a rapid pace, and trot around way more often than I believe is realistic. Even in the Hunter classic the deer were more docile and seemed to behave more realistic than this. I feel like tracking a deer is extremely difficult if not impossible. Granted, it should not be easy, but I feel like they just move too fast for you to effectively keep up.The noise mechanic is a nice feature of this game. However, I feel that the player character moves way too fast and makes too much noise. Sure, you must be careful and walk slowly, but I feel that crouch-walking the entire time is just not realistic/feasible. In real life, I can walk more carefully and tread lightly when needed. I know there are perks that can reduce walking noise, but it makes it hard to even kill anything and get to level up to get those skills. And then, since you have to crouch walk, you either cannot see the animals you are searching for, or you cannot keep up with a trail as the deer are moving away.I'm not saying we need slow moving, deaf zombie deer, but I think it still needs a little work.Now, I still recommend this game. I'm not a Hunter Classic player myself, but seeing how the devs have stuck with that game for so long gives me hope that they plan for this one to be around for a while too. I know tHuner Classic's subscription model might have been why they stuck with it for so long, so we will have to see. I do still have hope that they will fix this game and make it much better. The Hunter Classic 7 years ago would be laughable compared to what it is today. Let's hope they apply that work ethic to this title as well.If you're looking for a solid hunting game, that you can pay once for and get a full game, then I think this is your game... Once all of the wrinkles have been ironed out. But, if you're like me and just can't wait to jump in and scratch that hunting itch, then go for it! I will update this review as time goes on to see how well the devs keep up and fix the game, hopefully making it better!

content:
Posted: February 26
												Shot a fallow deer 5 times, tracked it for over 1 real time hour, game crashed before I found it. 10/10 too much waterEDIT:TL;DR - Enjoyable, feels like a beta but very pretty with an iffy interface, less of a hunting game and more an animal shooting game. Bows are OP. No microtransactions.After putting more time into this, I feel I can write a proper and serious review. At the time of writing, this game functions like beta. That said, despite being riddled with bugs and occasional crashes (though your mileage may vary on bugginess) this game is a graphically superb and worthy sibling to theHunter Classic, and I don't regret my purchase. My only major complaint is that they somehow managed to be less realistic in this game than Classic with both the general feel of the game and with animal behaviors - I feel I can describe it best in the way that Diablo 3 is not a dungeon crawler like D2, but a very large loot run. Similarly, you are placed in the vast reserve (and I do mean vast, the maps are colossal) with free reign over a never-ending hunt. It doesn't feel like hunting to me, it feels like animal shooting. Veterans of theHunter Classic (or even other hunting games, I suppose) might understand better than someone fresh to the genre. Animals, particularly female deer, are still dumb as walking rocks with the added bonus of sometimes running you over on accident in their zeal to be the first to stand as close to you as possible. Bright side? They don't seem to magnetize toward you anymore - they go where the call was and stick around the immediate area. You're free to sprint like a madman with (seemingly) little consequence. In fact, it seems rewarding by the warning calls provided by animals, alerting you to their rough location. Just crouch and spam your callers. Move toward them for increased efficiency. Animals also seem to be very nonchalant about gunfire, even within ranges where they would probably reasonably hear it. They also seem to not mind returning to the same area where you butchered several herd members already. That said - the hunting pressure system seems to mostly work. Animals outside the group (if there was one) you killed from are very unlikely to enter the area when attracted to calls or scents. They do, on occasion, wander through to get somewhere else, though.So far, weapons handle reasonably well and have satisfying sounds and animations, though I personally find the kick-up of recoil to sometimes be laughably extreme as an avid hunter in real life. The .243 is not as woefully pathetic as in Classic, and will absolutely do the work you need it to (until you can get the .270. Get it.). However, I recommend polymer tip bullets when available. They are a pleasant step up from the standard soft points, but certainly not a critical upgrade. Bows, however, seem grossly overpowered at the moment. Flesh wounds will have deer bleeding out in times comparable to decent rifle shots.The interface is a bit cumbersome and lacks information (e.g. current weapon scores outside of the shop, experience until next level, return to main menu button) that I would like to have access to, although this is more of a personal gripe than a point against the game. Most of the nitpicky issues I have with menus and interface are personal beyond being unrefined. The map also has the tendency to find itself focused on anywhere except where you are when opened.If I sound harsh on this game, it's not because these are glaring faults that should dissuade you from buying. This is a good game for the state it's in, but realize that it does have issues. I can recommend this to veterans of Classic that want a more streamlined and immediate hunting experience without fussing through menus and launchers or simply want to support Avalanche and Expansive Worlds. It's more of theHunter, what can I say? If you're on the fence or new to this series, perhaps stick with Classic until this game is fleshed out more.

Posted: February 17
												I've been watching this game since it went into Beta. The graphics look great, but the developers just fall short on the basics...- 3440x1440 has message boxes showing up off screen. Only the edges can be seen, while all of the text and general data is offscreen. Making it much harder to tell what is going on in game. Wide screen and custom resolutions are just basic functionality that should simply work on ANY PC game. If you don't support custom or at least standard resolutions, then you can't really call yourself a PC game in my opinion.- Going prone on an incline causes a graphical glitch allowing you to see through the world. How did this ever make it through both QA and Beta? This is another bug dealing with basic functinality. How do you produce a game that allows for prone and crawling and never once notice the clipping? Either that or they were simply too incompetent to fix it, neither of which is a good sign.- AI got stuck in the water. Two deer were walking in the water and just got stuck on nothing. While this bug is a little more forgivable given that these types of bugs generally require very specific locations/actions, on top of other basic functionality it all just points to Devs who either don't care about the quality of the game, or who are too incompetent to ensure the quality of the game. In either case I do not recommend buying it, though I will say it looks beautiful when it isn't glitching out.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Well lets start with specs.MSi Z97 Gaming 5 MoboG.SKILL Ripjaws X Series 16GBIntel Core i7 4790K Devil's CanyonCooler Master Hyper 212 HSFUFSP Group Aurum Gold 750wMSi GTX 960 Gaming 4G (x2) in Sli2x 250gb Samsung Evo 850 SSD - Raid 01x 500gb Samsung Evo 850 - StorageWindows 10 OSWith my current PC setup I have 0 issues with running on ultra 1440p as far as graphics are concerned.The game itself is beautiful and very detailed.  I can't say that I have seen a hunting game with better graphics.  The inital tutorial (If you use it)  was very straight forward and gives you good information in regards to gameplay.  Full controller support is a + but I didnt see any tutorial telling you how to better learn the controls if using a gamepad.  I opted for mouse and keys after discovering how clunky the controls felt on the 360 controller.Played the game and streamed it for a good 7 hours solid on launch day.  During the time playing I noticed more flaws then animals.  The deer seemed to be more responsive to calls then in classic.  They will literally run up withing 10m of you just to immediatly spook and run away.  So keep your eyes peeled for that and make sure you dont call them in when they are slowly heading your direction or they may just run right to you.Huntermate bug.  Having the huntermate in your hand and then pressing H to hide equipment swapping around then pressing Tab to bring up the huntermate actually brings up what looks like the face of an otterbax that your phone has fallen out of!   Whats this?!  Sure you can Tab around and get it back easily but hmmm.People with a poor quality internet connection, or beloew requirement PC can still play.  But be aware that you will Croush, Walk, and Run at least 10x slower then anyone else in game and you will rubberband around and have glitchy player animations.  I whitnessed all of this while playing with a friend that I am going to build a new PC for. I unlocked the bow!   YES! now that I've earned 10,000 and change I am going to buy the bow and some arrows and give that a shot.    Supprise Supprise....  I have EXPLODING arrows?!   While luring in an animal there I was.... Tucked under a tree for better cover and got my doe lured in at around 15m away.   I draw my bow and wait for her to turn.   Booom!  I fired my arrow to notice a flash and a giant puff of smoke come off the deer I shot.   Realistic?!  Hardly.While in a game and checking out the menu I noticed there is NO way of going back to home screen.  You simply have to Alt+F4 or you have to X out of the game and restart if you wish you start a new hunt or go from singleplayer to multiplayer.There are no micro-transactions in-game and I feel this is a good thing!  I feel that with how they marketed the game you should have to work for your gear which in turn will make it more enjoyable.  Simply being able to hop in and buy the guns you want, and anything you need with a micro-transaction seems to bring out the boredom and fast.I think in total having TheHunter (Classic) since 2011 and putting in over 300 hours on steam and well over 400 hours with the launcher from the site.  If you are looking into a new hunting game and have not tried TheHunter (Classic) then that is the game I would go for.There are many other glitches and bugs I have not mentioned in this post for Call of the Wild but believe me when I tell you they are there.  Expansive Worlds released this game too early and didn't spend the quality time required from a dev team to iron out majority of the glitches and bugs you are bound to discover if you download this game.Sure you are going to have bugs in a game. But for it not to be announced as early-access or beta.  There are too many in this game for it to be launched as a complete title.TheHunter (Classic) also has a vast array of species for you to hunt.  There are only 2 reserves and limited species to hunt on Call of the Wild as of yet.I'll leave the decision making to you the gamers, but if I had to choose now after only being 7 hours in.  This game needs some serious work.  Oh.... and waterfoul hunting.  ;)-FoX

content:
Posted: March 8
												I like it! Alot, actually. I haven't had any of the notorious crashes or bugs everybody's been talking about so far. Being an avid bowhunter our in the real world, there's alot in this game for me to like. So, let's get into it:Pros:-None of that monthly payment crap they did with theHunter classic, which I never played because of that.-Gorgeous game, period. -Good animal models.-So far, I like the animal behavior. It seems realistic enough.-The needs areas. It's about as realistic as you can get to areas where animals bed down and where large water sources are.-The hunting pressure system. Finally, a game does it. If you hunt out of one area all the time you're never going to find anything in there because it's all been chased out.-Realistic scent and sound mechanics. Keep an eye on the wind and watch your step. Keep your ears open for calls.-The sheer amount of space available to you. The reserves are large, to say the least.-It's ****ing hunting!Cons:-It doesn't say it's in early access, but it pretty much is. The lack of content shows, mostly in the weapons department. The game could use birds and more big game, too. -No traditional bows. I've used compounds all the way up to longbows. I use a recurve during the bow season, so the fact that it's isn't in the game bothers me. The compounds will have to do for now. -Bleed outs. The fact that the feature exists at all is excellent. However, they bleed out way too quickly. I get that it's a shot to the vitals, but they aren't going to run a hundred yards and just drop. They hole up and lay down, pretty much waiting until they die. Granted, it depends on how badly they've been shot, bow or rifle, but right now the distance run by the animals after the shot seems rushed and artificial. I can't speak for the bugs, because I haven't seen any yet, truth be told, but I like what I've played so far.Definitely a recommend from me.

content:
Posted: March 7
												So I've decided ro review for this game as I see the previous hunter game didn't get much recommendations.Firstly, this has to be the most beautiful game I've ever seen, it smashes any other game in terms of realistic colours and lighting, the sun bouncing off foliage is exactly replicated in this game and looks photorealistic when seen.Secondly, the sounds are absolutely perfect, running through wetlands, rustling through bushes, all the sounds are perfectly recreated in this world, you can even hear the equipment your wearing rubbing against the objects around you.Now I get onto the hunting, which is in it's early days and constantly being improved, the devs are hot on problems, and I no longer get crashes. There are few bugs, when playing for an extended amount of time, tracks and scents seem to stop being generated, making it almost impossible to hunt anything.The actual hunting in itself is pretty decent, there's a nice flow to tracking to stalking to then finally killing the game, animals will nearly always hear you if you walk or run, so following a "fresh" track normally means crouching and taking it slow, running around everywhere wont get you any results, so if you're impatient, or don't like waiting 20-30 minutes + for a shot, then you obviously have never been hunting! It's not all about stalking though, there are open areas where there may be drinking, feeding or resting areas, and near there, is most likely a chance to build a lookout stand, this is great fun if you dont want to be stalking, but requires patience as the area around you may only be visited at certain times of the day, so time management is key with sitting and waiting.Once you actually find something to shoot, it's not a matter of shooting it "wherever" there is an art to knowing where and when to shoot, shoot them in the wrong place, and you're basically being cruel and irresponsible. shoot them through the heart, you'll most likely get a clean and instant death, and PETA goes home happy.When you DO kill an animal, you'll get a reward based on the following, the animal you killed, whether it has a trophy rating, how long it took to die, the integrity of the shot (the right weapon choice) and obviously where the animal was shot. Getting a gold rating is always a big thing in this game, the ability to track, stalk and shoot an animal properly and cleanly, and this game graces the player when they complete this correctly.Overall, some of the things I would like to see in the future include small game hunting, as an Englishman myself, I hunt rabbits with night vision, and do alot of pest control, night vision sights would be a great addition to the game, but also small game hunting. another great addition would be birds, pheasants for the english, ducks for the americans, would be incredibly entertaining and I look forward to what the game brings in the future.I would recommend this game if you hunt in real life, if you don't this might be abit dull if you don't understand why this game is so good, but if your looking to buy something straight out rather than pay a subscription, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: March 7
												I have 380+ hours of theHunter: Classic under my belt so I think I've come to some conclusions after a dozen hours or so.I have had zero performance issues, crashes or the like to date and it runs slicker than dog poop on linoleum on my i5 and GTX 1060 6Gb. I don't find all of the claims of clipping and geometry issues to be any greater in extent than what I experienced in tH:C (theHunter: Classic, not THC). Is this a better game? Graphically yes and the gameplay is not far off of par in my opinion. They ruined the huntermate by changing a few things so that takes some getting used to. I enjoy the missions and perk points as a bit of a motivator to play and don't find the menu system to be all that difficult. Seriously so much salt over small potatoes.Yes, some of the animal behaviour is screwy and some of the calls seems a bit over the top but I would expect that with continual patching as seen to this point, some of this stuff can be tweaked.There are no micro-transactions or the idiotic 3 month license that tH:C forced you to repeatedly buy so this is a thumbs up for me. Haven't tried MP yet. May update if I do

number of helpful: 13 of 24 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20
												In short:While theHunter Classic could be called more of a hunting sim, Call of the Wild is an arcadey animal shooter, which was released utterly unfinished. Don't let the pretty landscapes and cheap(ish) price fool you; Avoid Call of the Wild like a plague until it's at least technically fixed and then hope they fire whoever whose idea this 'new direction' for the game was.Pros:+ Super pretty graphics+ No microtransactionsCons:- Unrealistic: Too many animals, which are near impossible to spook- Buggy: Encountered tons of glitches during 30min of gameplay- UnoptimizedMy experience:I loaded up the game and - after fiddling with the settings to make it run even semi-playably - decided to head out and find some game. Literally one minute after leaving the cottage I heard the warning call of a bear. I looked at the handy audio direction indicator and there the bear was, casually strolling at me. WTF?? I decided to take a shot at it. The bear reacted by taking a few running steps and then getting stuck on an invisible wall. I shot at it again, and again it took a few steps and stopped. This time it turned to face me head on and stare me with its big, quizzical eyes, as if it was hoping me to end its buggy virtual existence. I did.Now, in the original theHunter, running around and shooting your gun tended to have the side effect of making you unable to see a single hair of an animal for the next ~30 minutes. Not the case with this game, it seems! Just as I had finished slaughtering the poor Pooh, I SAW A BLACKTAIL DEER LOOKING AT ME, COMPLETELY PLACID. AND HEARD ANOTHER BEAR. What is this? Russian oligarch hunting simulator with tame animals tied down for you to shoot at on your private ranch?Thanks for turning the only somewhat respectable hunting simulator in the world into a dumbed-down shooting gallery for the Adderall generation. A bold move, I would say, as the niche appeal of the original game was the only thing keeping it afloat. Let's see how it pays off.EDIT: It is entirely possible the game was bugged and/or the game makes sure you see an animal the first time you play the missions. Or I just got extremely lucky. However, I wanted to keep my playtime short to keep my eligibility for the refund program, after seeing the glitches and framerate issues. I'm open to trying this game again at a later date - but at this time I cannot recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 10
												Overall...probably one of the best hunting games to date. If you are looking for a casual hunting game this is it. Expect a lot of walking, a lot of crawling, finding animals needs zones to hide out at for awhile, etc. Cons:It feels like its early access. Currently has a lot of bugs and some game crashes. I still consider it worthwhile though, even in its beta state. The missions are kinda dumb. But you can just bypass them and do whatever you want. For example: the missions are currently arranged in a way that makes it almost by chance to complete some of them...such as the take a picture of 2 bears in one pic. I personally hate the photography missions. This will most likely be fixed at some point.... but the animals sometimes get stuck on rocks, or freeze in space. This also will at some point be added: more animals and more content. Pros:None of that monthly pay crap they had in the first one. This is the reason i bought this one and nothing from the first one. Free roam. You can follow the story missions, side quests, or do whatever you want. Some scenery is so gorgeous it could be a background for your monitor.Huge enormous reserves. I havent even been to every location in almost 40 hours of gameplay. Bleed outs from animalstracking.......you can literally spend an hour in real time tracking an animal that you shot, it you hit the flesh and no vitals. hunting pressure zones. If you shoot an animal in the same spot, they come around less, if not at all. History. Their past game shows that they will work one this game for years to come. Adding content, fixing bugs, etc. etc.Realistic features.... sounds, smells, and visuals can give you away as a hunter.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												It's an excellent simulator of what hunting really is and should be like. There are some annoyances that I HOPE the developers keep in mind when releasing future updates, but for the most part the game is excelent.Pro's1. This game is beautiful. It is taxing on the system, but I am able to play on a steady 30 fps, and the textures are all at least 4k. Its amazing and I definetly applaude the developers for making it so.2. Realism of the process of hunting is outstanding. It goes through all the steps, and doesnt make it overly simplified to find prints or track animals.3. Animal diversity is also quite astounding.Con's1. The A.I of the animals needs a lot of tweaking. This is a problem that should be able to be remedied, but it is something that needs to be fixed in the future if the game is to be succesful. It kinda takes the realism out of the game when you finally track down a deer stuck in a tree, and shoot it point blank. Take collision with trees off at least?But other than that, the game is fineThere is not a whole lot more to a hunting game than what it already has guys. This isnt bass pro;s either, so they dont have an entire warehouse arsenal of hunting equipment for you to choose from. It's just the way it is and I can understand it.Overall 7.5/10, If the A.I is fixed 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												This game is as enjoyable as it is good looking; exploring dense forest, wavey plains and steep rock faces all in search of that perfect deer. You've got a decent selection of gear to choose from, such as bows and shotguns, bolt action rifles and lever action repeaters, scents and callers and ammuntion focusing on either penetrating thicker hides or causing more damage to the vitals. You'll be using these against several breeds of deer, fox, bears, herds of bison, moose and wild boar, all of which spread over two large open maps. One map takes place in Northern America and the other in rural Germany.This game still has a few flaws, however. The animal AI can sometimes get caught on the terrian or get stuck in pathing loop. Whenever you go prone, the camera can clip through the ground, revealing the vast nothingness below. The sound glitches and crackles when there is a lot going on.It you can look passed a few rough edges, you'll have a great hunting game on your hands. I've paid full price and I do not regret waiting for a sale. It you enjoy hunting games or exploring vast open worlds, then I highly recommend this game.

												Gameplay:Its not Call Of Duty in the Forest, where bears on steroids, 50 feet tall attacking innocent topless girls in mini skirts, and u save them - (btw I would love this kind of game) - this is slow paced, hunting simulator. My last hunt was tracking black bear for like 20 minutes, and then hit it from 250 meters in the head. It really was like real life hunting - you have shot statistics after hit, where did u hit animal and the score. Its really interesting. I can suspect there will be more DLCs like Alaska with Grizzly bears and stuff like this - which will make this game only better.Graphics are great, and you really have feeling being in the forest, moving slowly tracking your prey - if you like, slow paced games, where you have to think a lot, a truly hunting simulation - it is game for You.

content:
Posted: March 1
												Everything about the game, graphics, scenery, AI and much more are 100% phenomenal. I have been complete emersefied in the game since purchase. I like everything about it and would recommened it to any one that loves hunting with a few exceptions as listed below. 1.) Sometimes the animals glitch out while walking/running or after being shot. 2.) So far i have discovered a few watch towers and 1 camp, which gives you rewards such as perks, cash or skill points. The one thing i have noticed each time is i don't actually recieve my perk points, has happened 3 or 4 times now and mainly on finding the watch towers and a couple other times on some other things. I do how ever receive them for leveling up though just fine. 3.) I don't know if it has to do with how im playing or not but there seems to be a bit of lack on animal species spawn rates. Out of the 16+hrs played i see an animal on average of 1 time every 45mins of real world time not game time. I do however know the game is different if a new game is started up again and i mean new as is starting all over at level 1. The first time there seemed to be more spawn rates. I only started a new game as i was only level 3 and the wife wanted to learn how to play as well.4.) Currency relative to game play builds and purchases. I feel the game is a little over priced on guns,bows and ammo as prices range from 10,000 to 60,000 for rifles and ammo starts as 350.00 for maybe 5 to 10 shells, as i have spent 1000.00 on ammo for the .243 (starting rifle) and received around 60-80 rounds. The building cost of the stands vs animal kill cash prizes and other world findings is a little high as well, say around 25% higher than i think it should be. Im all the time building stands and but that cost effected me being able to purchase better guns.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28
												theHunter: Call of the Wild by Avalanche Studios, Expansive Worlds and astragon Entertainment might just be the “ground-breaking open world hunting simulator” you’ve been waiting for. The game implements realistic animal behavior, ballistics, and even weather cycles. There is not much of a tutorial and the player is dropped into the world with a gun and a map. Although there are initial voice overs and some tips, the player is pretty much left to their own devices.In regards to gameplay, the tracking mechanic can prove to be both frustrating and exciting. This is perhaps what lends it so well to creating an immersive experience that feels pretty real. While deer don’t have glowing prints, it is difficult not to feel excited when you realize you are getting close to one of the many types of wildlife in the game. It is also important to be on edge because many of the animals can turn and attack at a moment’s notice. It is hard not to feel excited when you finally line up that shot and pull the trigger. This game’s ballistics really alter the success of each shot based off of distance and trajectory so accuracy matters.However, I did find a few issues with the game. Due to the sheer size of the map and it being rendered all at once, the game is both beautiful and sometimes laggy. When prone I noticed that the grass does not connect to the ground, which caused clipping and obstruct the path at times. The most noteable glitch was a moose stuck in a hillside that would not die until it was shot five times. This is a big deal when ammo is limited and weapons are difficult to unlock in the beginning. There is also an auto walk feature, which is nice when walking great distances, but problematic when collecting trophies. This is because when doing so the game does not pause and you can walk off a cliff, be attacked by a bear, or both in my case.You can read the full review here {LINK REMOVED}http://bit.ly/GCypher7336

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												Dont know why this is getting bad reviews. I played the first game and the feeling it gives you is like no other. This sequel based on the very short time i have played it (just a bit over an hour i think) is just like the first in giving you that feeling. Its very zen like.... until you find your prey... then the anxiety is turned to 11. Most games are incapable of doing this. This game is very special. If you have this on your wish list or it interests you. Buy it. Bascially the game drops you into the middle of a large german hunting reserve. It takes you on a short tutorial on how to move around and do stuff and then abruptly sort of lets you do whatever you want. If you played the first hunter game you know there is no real.... DIRECTION you are supposed to go. Its a hunting game so you have to find where to go. Be it in the form of a sound. a track. poop. or even an animal in the distance. Once this happens the game gives you directions to follow in the form of azimuth. And in the case of tracks , it points you in the rough direction of your next set of tracks which glow blue.  Its a very zen like experience. This is also the longest part of the game. It can take quite a long time to track an animal. My first play through was just 1 deer and it took 40 minutes. And I shot at it multiple times and had to start tracking it again. This is frustrating but realistic. eventually when you end up hitting a deer , depending on where , it will start bleeding. This will start leaking on the ground and giving you a new set of tracks to follow. If you shot the deer in a good spot. It will slowly or quickly start to bleed out. And you follow the blood trail to the body. Then you harvest the deer and get your points. There are other animals in the game but i have not seen them yet.It also has , what i would have to say the best environmental graphics of any game ever made. I dont know WHAT kind of magic the developers did with lighting and foliage. But taking screenshots in this game is almost as fun as playing it. If you are old enough to experience CRYSIS when it first came out on PC , you know what its like to be completely blown away by graphics. I have not had that feeling since today. It really is a technological marvel Give these devs your money. And make sure to leave a review. I dont understand where the negative reviews are coming from

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31
												I picked up this game and started playing it on average computer. It was nice but I realized it was not running as it should. I was ready to give it up. Then I decided to buy a new gaming pc OMG this game comes to life on a good computer, gone is the slow hunter. I am the Ben Johnson of hunters!! This game is amazing in so many ways.if you are looking for easy go play something else. You have to treat this game like real life. Do you have a tutorial in real life?? I don't! You also won't start to enjoy the game until you get to around level 4. Have you ever been driving late at night and you are a little tired on a two lane highway? You know when your trying to stay awake and think ever bush is a deer or moose about to jump in front of you?? This  game does that!!  You swear that I'm the distance deer are bushes you squint your eyes trying to see but no that's just a bush not a deer!! Lol The people that say there are no animals? Just like real life the animals on this game are WILD!! Do you think they want to be shot and killed and eaten by me?? Heck no. They run and hide when they hear your noisy♥♥♥♥♥coming. They smell your old spice aftershave you splashed on this morning. Don't be stupid!! WILD animals are smarter than you!!You have to go slow, sure you can run to a place. But then your sure going to have to wait for things to calm down again after all the human noise you just made!!I myself have encountered very few problems with the game now that I'm running a 1070 video card and i7 processor. I'm on max setting on everything and it looks and feels like real life.The calls take a bit to get used to. Start with the small black one it travels further. The deer will come to you after awhile in the right location. When they get a little closer switch to the can call. I had one today come so close he was almost on top of me!!! Then I was so excited I missed from 5feet  away lol . Just remember if you kill something move on because that area is full of the animals dead smell now lol great feature, it makes you move on and explore more.This is bar none the best and most realist hunting game out there by far!!  I have much more to unlock and I am super happy with how it's going so far. I can't wait to see what else is in here!Great game with so many options on what you can do. Walk around or just find a place to bring them in. Buy this if you have the computer to run it! And they taste great too!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												The game would not load at first at all, always crashed on startup every time. Tried a lot of things, even complete uninstall - re-install. Game files integrity check etc, you name it…After following this thehunter: "Customer support: http://support.thehunter.com/hc/en-us" (https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://support.thehunter.com/hc/en-us), which takes you to ->  http://support.thehunter.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003549987-My-game-won-t-start-from-Steam-Game-crashesThen doing this step;6) Try setting your Screen Space Reflections to 'On'.You can do this in the graphics settings in the main menu, in game menu or through the following method out of game:C:\Users\USER\Documents\Avalanche Studios\theHunter Call of the Wild\Saves\settings\STEAMUSERID>settings.json then set "GraphicsSSReflection": 0 to 1 Fixed EVERYTHING!!Game works fine now.

Posted: February 26
												Gameplay:Its not Call Of Duty in the Forest, where bears on steroids, 50 feet tall attacking innocent topless girls in mini skirts, and u save them - (btw I would love this kind of game) - this is slow paced, hunting simulator. My last hunt was tracking black bear for like 20 minutes, and then hit it from 250 meters in the head. It really was like real life hunting - you have shot statistics after hit, where did u hit animal and the score. Its really interesting. I can suspect there will be more DLCs like Alaska with Grizzly bears and stuff like this - which will make this game only better.Graphics are great, and you really have feeling being in the forest, moving slowly tracking your prey - if you like, slow paced games, where you have to think a lot, a truly hunting simulation - it is game for You.

content:
Posted: March 10
												Outstanding looking game with a lot of potential, but the game is basically an Early Access title. Lots of bugs that needs fixing and there are some problems within the game such as the currency system (takes like 4 hours of hunting to get 1 rifle that is barely better than the first one you start with), and the travelling in this game - oh man.. There are 2 maps in the game that are both vast and beautiful, but you have to walk/run EVERYWHERE. There is a fast travel option but you need to travel to the hunting lodge in order to unlock it. Basically everything in this game needs a slight tweak of some sort. The devs have been communicative and I trust that they will straighten things out to make this game what it needs to be.For now, I can't recommend this game until they fix some of the major problems and add much-needed content.

												The open world and scenery is simply amazing. While you maye need a moderately powerful computer to play this game to get the "full beauty", you  can still be left awed by the many sights. Are there bugs? Well yes, all new games have bug's. If you have ever let that be the reason you got fed up with a game and give it a poor review, thats not a good reason in my opinion.  Pros; open world, relatively cheap, no licenses for animals, infinite starter ammo, hud is easy to follow, and more.Cons; tracking at first is confusing, menus seem chunky and slow/freeze, small graphic errors/lag.With more time things will get ironed out and improved upon, making the game smoother and even more enjoyabe.  Just remember this isn't thehunter classic and plays differently but shares some simular key features. Most importantly be patient and have fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												March 6th 105 hours in...I have to say STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAMETHE BUGS ARE WORSE THAN EVER AFTER PATCHES.SO FRUSTRATING YOU WILL WISH YOU COULD SHOOT YOURSELF IN THE FACE. But you can't because one of the bugs is you lose your weapons. You cannot unlock blinds and towers. I wasted 5 hours doing that only to log back on and have all green question marks on the map again. Tracks, blood trails and animals keep dissapearing even after a fresh start. Low fps,Glitchy inventory which you can access once in awhile. It will move your quick access items. Have had crashes, Sound looping, and multiplayer games where some people can't see animals. The devs are busy changing prices on items making them 3x original prices, cause I guess its important to tweak game play instead of fix broken game problems. There is no quit to menu button, Animal Ai is horrible. We play in multiplayer just hoping to find a herd of buffalo stuck in the rocks so we can waste them as the bury their heads in the dirt with their hind legs kicking in the air futely running to nowhere. ITS A FKN HUNTING SIM. You think that animal AI might be on the top of your priority list. Also you cannot get some animal callers even 105 hours into game. That's great. Lets have prey running around you cannot call in. You can just randomly hope to run into one and kill it. RIGHT because most of the people buying this are going to play 100 + hours to try and unlock everything. Hence them changing prices and level caps etc. THEY HAVE NO CLUE WHAT THIS GAME IS. They boast about making it more arcade style so they can still support hunter classic. 100 hours into a game and still having stuff locked is not arcade stlye. You have no concept of what your own game is. The maps are so big and you have to run everywhere. No vehicles. You have to find the outposts before you can even jump to them. That would be fine if AUTO RUN didn't kill you half the time on your way there. I have tried to be patient with this game. BUT AS OF TODAY MY PATIENCE RAN OUT. There are MANY MORE problems with this game. Many of which existed from beta testing right through release. STAY AWAY FROM THIS UNFINISHED TURD!!!!10 hours in or so...updateOK This game just won me over!! Here's why I just had a great moose hunt. Learning only shoot one animal. you can track a vital hit animal for 15 minutes or more this game is not easy.  Then I had the best hunt ever. A black bear 100 yards out I shoot him. He's running I shoot him again at 200 yards he's still running I shoot him a 3rd time...all of this within 10 seconds. I go in to find the track. (oh don't forget to reload) I come in 300 yards I just get to where I last saw him...and out of the bush he charges BANG I shoot him again at 10 yards, gun recoils I'm shaking I cant see, he's still charging. I get my trusty ranger under control and down just in time to drop him with a 5th shot at 4.44 yards...I LOVE THIS GAMEI am now changing my review to recommend. If you love hunting this is a great adventure game.lets keep those updates and patches coming though ;)Editing as time goes on:After 6 hours or so I would like to update and add the following. I am a die hard hunting game follower having played every deer hunter back in the day, trophy hunts, cabela's and a host of others. In real life I am a hunter. (Harvested 3 whitetail this last fall).  This game is the best looking I have ever played. I have seen some cool things in this game. My first kill was a fox. I shot the fox he ran off. Narrator says he's not going far. And boy was he right. Out of the bush 2 black bears burst and grabbed my fox. I never saw it again...LOLThis is a good game. It has not crashed on me once in my 6 hours. The little bugs are just soooo annoying. I will change this review to positive when the bugs are ironed out.This game has POTENTIAL. As long as the dev is fixing and adding this will be a great game!Original reviewWell I have to agree with the negatives on this board. Too many bugs to play right now. We pay full price for this and its unplayable. Very annoying. Yes I see there are patches coming out and they are working on it. Why would you release this game with all of the same problems listed by beta testers. That's bad mojo on your part. I knew that coming into this and was so stoked to play the game I bought it anyway. Now I have faith that it will be fixed and sooner rather than later.bugs I found in my first couple of hours:Bought bow bought ammo. (3x) no ammo in inventory cannot use bow. FRUSTRATINGcannot zoom with controller setupcannot select menus with controller setupjoining multiplayer game issuesGame does not save sound menu changesInventory menu does not workHeadlamp will not turn offDeer caught on structuresdeer shot 4 times at close range would not die....just ran in circlesHunter stats are not correct. shows wrong number of shots and accuracy numbersLow FPS on high end machineOn the bright side:game looks and sounds greatlarge mapsdecent price for full gamesupport is coming (2 patches already)in conclusion you get points for support...but then I have to ask why did you release this game in such a poor state?
