content:
Posted: March 6
												My TheHunter: COTW Review. Graphics: The graphics are very pretty and really well done but it is sorta a wool cover over our eyes on whats hiddenly broken about this game. Hunting: You have to either get a rare one hit shot on the game your hunting and take it down in that one shot but most of the time you will find yourself shooting an elk or bear or boar more than enough to take it down doesn't matter if you shot it in the spine or leg it well still be able to run. Also you can't hunt small game such as rabbits or other small critters same goes for birds you can't hunt those either. Also it would be interesting if they add fishing that is a form of hunting.Shop-Locker: You spend hours gathering enough money for that one rifle you wanted for some reason it's more than 1k but you buy it anyways just to realise that you just spent $42,000 on a basic looking rifle no carved animals on it's stock no gold or silver enlays nothing just wood maybe some cheap camo bullet holder on the side nothing fancy isn't like you just spent aton of money. Then you notice for $680 you can get a signle pack of 10 rounds for your said rifle. "Side Note" irl you can get a deer hunting rifle as cheap as $350 and for $20 you can get some hunting rounds for a scope it can be very cheap like the rifle or less or it can rack your price up to 6 times the price of the rifle. Menu: Just a basic menu nothing fancy and once in the game there isn't a exit to the menu only to desktop. Now this well probably be fixed soon but doesn't change that they placed a game for $30 on the market without adding a main feature into the game it's self. So ill keep this in the review. UI: Nothing fancy just a somewhat see through tiny box that tell you your ammo count heart rate a basic campos that's about it even your smartphone gps looks basic the one from TheHunter looks more well done and better. Now of course in time there might be an update where they make the ui look way better but as of now it makes me think our hunters we are playing have a pair of google glasses on that's how bad it looks maybe have a more realistic looking map or have a campos that looks like something a hunter or hiking has. Maybe the ammo count is a pouch or something so it's more realistic looking either way it doesn't look that great. Realisim: Now i know it's a video game but it's trying to be like a realistic hunting sim. I feel like just playing it these devs didn't do any research they were doing far more research in making the 2 maps look as realistic as they could or pretty as they could. Instead of going on irl hunting trips or just watching videos on it. Something that can give them a taste on what it is like. Also there's something called google all they had to do was look up hunting sites on how much hunting clothing cost same goes for all these weapons and ammo. Then how it is now in the game where it almost feels like a pay to win but you can't pay with real money only in game. Weapons: Where is all the 22's and air rifles. That's what id want to see people hunt with those type of weapons in Euro and Germany same with the west. Gameplay: You well be able to spend lots of hours hunting unlocking new weapons exploring messing around in multiplayer. Finding all the relics or easter eggs. Climbing up high places taking pics of animals. Just enjoying the view it's a very nice game if you always wanted to hunt or you just like the outdoors but you are mostly in doors. Updates: There well be updates soon or later that well fix these issues just wait and in time everything well be fixed also there well probably DLC's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												Let me get one thing clear straight away, I love this game! It hits all the right notes and I just hope so bad that the devs keep updating the game and adding new content. I played Classic but really didnt like how expensive everything was; as soon as I saw they were creating a one time payment game I couldnt wait.The graphics and the audio for the most part are fantastic, while I would like to increase the draw distance its not as bad as the TheHunter Classic. There are a few sound bugs every now and then, epecially when you are close to water and its raining, the audio starts clipping and looping. Also I dont know how AA works in the game but I would like to be able to change it as I can still see jagged edges everywhere when in 1080.Multiplayer is a lot of fun but this is where most of the work is needed; I have only played multiplayer for a few hours and there has been quite a few bugs. I have had a game where the other person couldnt hear or even see any of the animals that I could, another game where the other person couldnt get any of his items out even though they were in his inventory, and perhaps the worst thing for me with multiplayer is that only the host can unlock new camps, lookouts and anything else you can click on. Also we have to take it in turns to claim downed animals because only the person that harvests the animal gets a reward and there is no way to tell who hit it without clicking to harvest it. Apart from the above problems I really have had a great time playing this game, I love the feeling of tracking an animal through forests and fields only to finally get that shot you wanted and hope that the animal doesnt run off for miles while spilling blood everywhere. You get a great feel of acomplishment with this game and it can be very rewarding. The items are quite expensive and take a long time to get and levelling is very very slow which is a pain when your waiting for those new skills and perks you so desperately need.Things I would like to see added:1. More animals - a lot more, especially birds as currently you cant harvest any flying animals.2. More guns, scopes and other items like tents, portable hunting encloures, etc.3. Missions for multiplayer, not everyone wants to go against each other, coop missions would be nice.To me the game is still in early access but after some updates and new content I think this could be an amazing game. I know some of the new content will be DLC but I hope a good portion of it is free as the game does lack a bit of content at the moment especially in the flying department.If and when things change I will update my review as necessary.

content:
Posted: March 11
												The Hunter Call of the Wild is essentially a first-person shooter. Unlike most shooters, though, you don't get shot. You shoot or try tho shoot game like deer, foxes, and bison. You hunt this game in a forest in Europe. This forest is very beautiful with lush vegetation and has weather effects like wind, rain, and fog. The terrain is varied being fairly flat in some places and mountainous in other places. The forest is huge and can take a long time to traverse. Fortunately there are outposts scattered about the forest. Once discovered, you can fast travel to other outposts in other areas of the map.On the downside, the game requires a lot of patience. You can play for an hour or more without seeing any game. When you do see game, it is very skittish and will run off even when you are far away from it. If you do shoot an animal it may run off leaving you empty handed. A bug in the game sometimes causes the animals to run in place. You can shoot them point blank without killing them.Is The Hunter for you? If you like something that can simulate hunting, then it might be a good choice. It does lend a feeling that you are actually stalking animals in the woods. When you do get a kill, it can be a satisfying experience. The map can be fun just to explore. For those of you who want much to do much of the time, this game probably won't please you.Is The Hunter for me? I've found that it does get better the more I play. It is a bit different from most of the shooters I play, and I've been looking for something different. I'm also pleased with the graphics. I'd say The Hunter is fair, and that's why I rate it three stars.You may wish to consider Far Cry 3, Far Cry 4, and Far Cry Primal. Theses games allow you to hunt game along with battling enemies. Unlike The Hunter, these games are much faster paced and animals much less difficult to hunt.

Posted: March 19
												I've played 10 hours so far, and can say that this game is absolutely amazing.  The graphics are amazing and the all around atmosphere of the game is fantastic.  So far I have run into a couple of bugs, one being that animals will get stuck on trees and keep running into them, so it's basically a free kill.  Other bugs i have found are that the .223 rounds in the store are backwards, being that the soft point and polymer tips got mixed around, and finally if you are using binoculars and you press Esc and go back to the game, the binocular's outline will still be on your screen until you look through them again.  But other than these little bugs, this game is still fantasic.

												Positive-The World is awesome, it looks really nice, the trees, the light, the climatology...-The map is gigantic, with variety of landscapes and geographical accidents.-Arms recreation it's so good too.-Simulation oriented.-Missions; some are really difficult and require a lot of time and luck, it can be like a kind of challenge.Negative-Lots of constant bugs. Animals dancing in circles, rotating in the air or stuck in trees or rocks. The Whole pack of buffalo weirdly trapped in a hillside doing strange movements and noises, you can kill them one by one and them don't run away. Sometimes you'll die in the middle of the forest for no reason. Strange view rotations. Bugs are constant. Everytime you play you'll see something weird.-Animals lack of AI oftenEither way i'm not fully dissapointed with the game, i think that deserves patience. If the team are working on the rigth fixes this could be a very good game. But now, for me, it's the seed of a good game that should be on development or testing till it grows.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												First i just want to say Its not my intension to bash or "♥♥♥♥♥♥talk" this game!   I have a love/hate relationship to this game atm.  I had a good few hours in the online game before this came out and loved it.  This game on the other hand I'm still not to sure about.   I have played this game for 20 + hours the last few days and have made a little list of pros and cons.  There will be more cons then pros atm but that does not mean i dont like the game, i just feel like its not at its full potential.   CONS!  1: In the settings u can choose between toggle aim or to hold the aim with right mouse and this works for a few "aims" and its just reset to default again.  2: The waypoint system is either bugged or its the weirdest waypoint system i have ever seen in a game! When you place a waypoint on the map it shows how long it is to the place you want to go , but it also shows up in the opposite direction of where you want to go and its just confusing.  3: Animals get stuck in trees and bushes.  4: Animal trails disappear  5: When you og prone you can see under the map at some locations and that can make you shoot the map instead of the animal you are hunting.  6: Missions with taking pictures of the animals is so bugged and it took me 1-2 hours to  finish the mission! And i took more then 50 pictures of the deer! The mission where u have to take pictures of the 2 or more bears is impossible "At least for me" honestly i dont think the picture missions should be in the game... 7:  And then the most annoying bug for me at the moment is a shotgun bug! I used the shotgun to takedown a deer at close range and now when i shoot at any animal with any gun it says i used the shotgun, and that means i cant do some missions since the game thinks i used the shotgun at a mission where I'm only allowed to shoot with a rifle! 8: The maps is large! Very large! And that means a lot of walking around... It takes forever to get to the destination you need to be! This can be fixed with cars,atv,bikes, horses or any vehicle. It would help a lot!  9:Places to rest/sleep/fast travel to is just to far apart if u could buy a tent to take with u so u can sleep outside without having to fast travel to a camp it would make it way better.  PROS!  1: The game graphics is beautiful and feels well done! 2: The way you track animals is brilliant! The fact that u have to turn on your light at night to see the tracks just makes it even better. 3: Leveling system feels good and its interesting. U can choose from a large amount of skills and perks 4: Never had a crash or big fps drop " You do need a ok pc to run at ultra " 5: Missions is fun and a good way to make some cash to buy new guns and tools. 6: There is a good choice in weapons and tools to buy in the game. It can feel like a grind to get the cash to buy them at times but that just mean that you have to hunt more 7: This can be an awesome hunting game or u can just go on a killing spree if u want it up to you.  If u play the way i think its meant to be played it feels like a brilliant hunting game!  This game does not feel like its finished, not even close! BUT it is still an amazing game if u give it a chance. Its buggy at times, and i have to be honest i hate this game at times... But i know it has a lot of potential if the devs can fix some of the worst bugs and maybe add a few things to it. I'm gonna continue to play it and hope the game gets better.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Still crashes after 2 patches on a GTX 1080, 1440p G-Sync monitor.This could be a really good game but there's one issue which ruins it for mouse+keyboard users, the lack of being able to move slowly. If you want to move slowly without creating max noise then you'll need a joypad, even then it's not great as there's such a fine line between faster speed and no speed, you can adjust some joypad settings but no setting to actually adjust sensitivity for walking. It also feels dumbed down, sure you can make things harder by removing glow for the tracks but it still feels dumbed down, seems to be over populated with animals, there's also a stupid feature called "warning", basically the creature will hear you and make it's voice sound. Why on earth have such a stupid feature, it's like the developers have said ok how can we make the player find the various creatures easily, stupid. I mean a creature isn't going to shout out a warning if you're getting close because you made too much noise, stupid and dumbed down.The game looks really nice, much better than the 1st game and runs great at Ultra setting but does crash some sessions.You basically level up through xp, buy things, do missions. As for competitions, if you're expecting them to be like hunter classic, forget it. It's poorly implimented, noone bothers with them, they're not global.Multiplayer is pointless without well run competitions, noone bothers with them.If you've never played classic thehunter then you might like it, but for those that played the ortginal you'll be let down somewhat despite the great graphics.I'll continue to play it and hope they improve things soon but can't really reccomend it as a successor to TheHunter because it falls short in many ways.

content:
Posted: April 21
												For those of you who really enjoy hunting in games like myself, this is a very good attempt at what it would be like to go out and hunt in the wild. Sure it's riddled with bugs (i've only experienced a few) But the feel, the sounds, the excitement of bagging your first buck is a feeling i haven't felt in a long time. I love hunting in games, it's one of my favorite things to do and this captures it almost perfectly. Though keep in mind, hunting is a very slow and methodical sport. You should deticate some time and effort to it, you can't just run everywhere and shoot deer in the head all the time. I mean you can, but thats not the point of the game and you wont get a whole lot of points for it.  Also while hunting doe isn't advised in real life, i would actually encourage it as they're much more common and you still get xp and cash towards new gear that is much needed. Those worried about licenses, i remember Primal needing you to buy licenses to hunt anything outside of whitetail but in my experience i can hunt whatever is out there with no consequence. It's a must-have for hunting fans.

content:
Posted: April 20
												This might be the most beautiful game I have played so far on my PC. The environments are drop dead gorgeous. There are a few kinks to work out and I would like to see a larger range of weapons included but overall this is one of the best experiences I have had as a PC gamer who also loves the outdoors. It's as close to real as a game can get, still way simpler of course, but they do a decent job of simulating it. The world itself is HUGE and it takes forever to walk somewhere, luckily they have made the wildlife pretty abundant so usually you don't have to go more than a few hundred meters to start tracking down something. Night hunting adds a whole new level of challenge and I reccomend giving it a shot, even though in my part of the world it's completely illegal and extremely frowned upon.

content:
Posted: April 22
												This game is very fun and has many positive elements.  I would highly recommend the game provided you understand before purchase you are going to be waiting for bug fixes.  The core game of sneaking up on or ambushing prey in the wild is very solid.  The game has many, many bugs.  The firearms, beyond the starting rifle, seem like they need some improvements.  The bullets seem to matter more than the firearms.  It seems to me that penatration is king and so a 357 magnum with the pen bullets is much better than the more expensive 44 magnum with the soft bullets.  This may be by design but it makes progression feel a little wierd when you buy new guns and have to wait to use them till you unlock better bullets.  The most annoying thing for me is the rain.  I very much hope they either tune down how often it rains or add a volume slider for just the rain sound effect.  Rain is so loud you cant hear anything else if your on discord or listening to music, etc.  You could turn down the main volume but then you cant hear prey walking around close to you.  Multiplayer needs alot of work.  You can lock yourself out of being able to use outpost, even in single palyer, for fast travel if you click on flag poles in a multiplayer sessions and you did not have them unlocked in single player already.  This game is very fun but could be a AAA if they can get the bugs squashed and add a few improvements and some more content.  The dev team has something really special in this games overall design and execution and i'm really looking forward to seeing the game get better over time.  The game is a recommend at it's current price.

content:
Posted: February 26
												habe das game jetzt ca. 4 stunden gespielt. nur im Multiplayer mit Freunden... leider musste ich feststellen das der Multiplayer nur für den Host "attraktiv" ist. Denn es ist nur dem Host möglich, die einzelnen Map-Punkte (u.a. "Aussenposten" "interessante Orte" und "Aussichtspunkte") zu erkunden. Die anderen Mitspieler können lediglich Jagen und dafür Punkte bekommen. Apro pos Punkte: Diese werden auch nur dann verteilt wenn man auf ein Tier geschossen hat, wenn dem nicht so ist, bekommt man rein gar nichts....Fazit:-) Multiplayer sollte ausgereift werden - alle Mitspieler sollten Waypoint aktivieren können.-) Gemeinsames Jagen sollte verbessert werden - Belohnungen beim Jagen sollten alle erhaltne, nicht nur wenn man draufgeschossen hat.-) Falldamage anpassen, da nicht realistisch. Man kann von einem Aussichtspunkt hinunter springen und man erleidet einen sehr geringen Schaden! Beim Springen auf eine Holzbank ist man tot. usw.-) Zielfernrohr ist manchmal verbuggt - das zoomen bei der Waffe funktioniert nicht korrekt, man sieht durch das Zielfernrorh und sieht dabei seine Hände und das Rohr ist extrem klein!-) Menü funktioniert nicht korrekt: Eine Auswahl ist manchmal nicht möglich, man muss 2-3 mal klicken.-) Muitionskauf: Man kann diese zwar kaufen, aber man sieht nicht wieviel Munition man gekauft hat. Nur wenn man aus dem Menü raus geht und die Waffe auswählt. Im "Lager" wird die Munition ebenfalls irgendwann angezeigt...-) Kein Zurück zum Haupt-Menü: Man muss andauernd das Spiel beenden und neustarten.-) usw. - ich hoffe die Entwickler sehen diesen Beitrag und werden diese Bugs ausbessern.... leider ist es mir nicht mehr möglich das Spiel zurückzugeben, sonst würde ich das auch machen!Für mich ist es eine Alpha-Versiojn und überhaupt nicht ausgereift! - Unbedingt Updates notwendig! - Keine Kaufempfehlung!

content:
Posted: February 19
Product received for free
												The slow pace of hunting, the minimalistic UI, the sounds, and gorgeous graphics makes theHunter an impressively immersive experience that manages to be pretty relaxing and thrilling at the same time. The gameplay is in my short experience pretty simplistic, which is probably a necessity given that it's a pretty unique game. You find a trace, you follow it, you shoot the animal, everybody happy. It certainly has depth though, and the world feels very alive, despite pretty much just being you, the land, and the animals. I would attribute this to the AI of the animals combined with the mechanics of the world more than anything, as they'll pretty realistically react to noises, sightings, et cetera.My main gripes with the game seem to be things that will hopefully be improved upon in later patches. Namely, the tutorial is more or less just text boxes popping up every once in a while. Even though learning through playing might work, there's a good few mechanics that just aren't explained all that well and given how this isn't a common/mainstream type of game, a proper tutorial would really make it easier to get into the game.Secondly there's a slight lack of polish in some areas. Menus are a bit clunky and there are some smaller graphical bugs. The positional audio could use some work too, it would be an amazing asset to the immersion but there's just something off about it in terms of volume levels and direction.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												So I'm just about 10 Hours into the game, so first impressions I think are in order. A little background, for the longest time I wanted to get "the Hunter: Classic", but I wasn't interested in shelling out the cash that the reviews mentioned. So then this came along and I jumped on it. I had finally gotten the "the Hunter" experience I was hoping for; unfortunately, it also came with those things I've learned to expect from this industry. Those things you hate, you know, those dirty little bugs.  Anyways, while I applaud the devs for abandoning their previous pay-to-win business model and not succumbing to the "early access" model (that plagues the industry); they certainly shouldn't have released the game without some sort of heads up that it was in fact very much in early access stages. So with all that said I'm going to try and point out what I've noticed the devs did right and what they did wrong(In hopes they'll read this and patch this beautiful ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game). Pros:- The game is ♥♥♥♥ing gorgeous.- The sound is pretty damn impressive, mainly the ambient noises(wind, leaves, rain, etc) and atmosphere they create.- Love the weapon handling. It can be a ♥♥♥♥♥, but it seems fairly accurate to RL gun handling.- Pretty fair price for content. The maps are massive, and you'll find yourself constantly being distracted while exploring them. - Good :/ AI. It's nice to see a studio that can manage at least getting the AI in a sandbox environment like this without it completely bugging out **cough** DayZ **cough**. When you are stalking animals you just can't go gallivanting through the woods and expect to ever find anything. I think last I checked around 6 hours in, I had scared some 600 animals away from noise alone cause I was just out running around trying to find the nearest cabins. You have to be all predator like and pop up being like BOOOOOOM HEADSHOT. No you should shoot them in the heart... it's more "humane" < better trophy. Cons: - Let me start with the most outrageous one of all. NO 'Back to Menu' button, that's right! HOW in the hell did you guys miss that one in said "Beta", the♥♥♥♥ how did you guys not catch that in Alpha. You mean to tell me, when I get into: a buggy game, a slow server/ host connection game, get stuck in the water, or want to switch from multiplayer to single player.... I have to exit and restart the entire game?!?!? Save us someone! We are going 1 step forward 10 steps back here. - Multiplayer in general seems to be a buggy mess. Bad D-Sync, characters stuck in walk, spawning in with no ammo, spawning in and immediately dying, awful hit registration, you name it they got it there it would appear. I have had a very minimal amount of bugs in single player. - In single player I've had interaction bugs, where I literally can't click on anything. I'll give you an example of how unbelivably frustraiting this one is. So I walked ALL the way to one of the northern most cabins to only find out once I had gotten there that I couldn't click on anything. I had to restart my game( ^ since I couldn't close to menu and spawn back in), and when I spawned back I was all the way at the southern most cabin. I would have to walk all the way back to that cabin to gain fast travel access since I couldn't claim the spot before the bug appeared. - Hit registration in single player seems to be an issue as well. I had shots that I just know I didn't miss, shots that were point blank, and I would hit nothing but air. No blood, not even a flesh wound.

content:
Posted: February 19
												This review is for people on the fence about this game like I was. This has to be the most beautiful game I have played too date I mean when it's graphics are cranked up its photo realistic. The gameplay it's self is solid with easy to learn controls and a fairly large amount of things to collect and do. The animal AI is either super realistic or on occasions a deer in front of headlights but overall great AI. I see a lot of people complaining about bugs which I have encountered maybe two neither of which are game breaking and can easily be fixed by the devs.So would I recommend this game to the average gamer? Definitely, it's emersuve in the best way and you can spend hours just walking around the environment. And when you finally get the kill on an animal you've been tracking for the last 20 mins it's so rewarding. WARNING! This game is hard to run so make sure to do some research before you buy it to make sure you can run it. My system specs Rx 480 16gb ram AMD 8320 Windows 10

content:
Posted: March 2
												Should be an early access game. Lots of unfinished descriptions on weapons. Unbalanced stats on tools and weapons. Broken hitboxes and bullet clipping (Shot a deer point blank in the heart, said I got his spine). Missing "Return to main menu" button (Lol?). Optimization needs some tuning. Ai needs some touch ups. But after all that, the game looks pretty in ultra, it has great potential, no micro-transactions, my entire map has become purple, get destroyed by three bears at once and can become robbin hood with my trusty bow. I suggest faster ways of getting around such as an atv or pick-up. Im sure devs are already on that. But overall I see great potential in this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												This game has met all my expectations and a little more even, yea it has bugs but the devs are working on fixes around the clock. first ill start off with the pros.PROS- Sound quality is extremly detailed and some of the best ive heard in any outdoor/hunting game (sounds just like real life imo)- The graphics are really good compared to classic- The environments and animals are incredibly detailed and super realistic- Animations look as life like as if you were actually watching a real deer- AI is decent although it could be better (for example the animals call way to often and ocasionally walk into trees and get stuck)- The missions are fun and keep you wanting to play more of them- The reserves are absolutely massive and it would definitly take a long time to have explored every inch of hunting area- One time purchase with no micro transactions whatsoever (A big improvement over TheHunter classic)- Leveling seems balanced although if you dont play some of the missions it will take significantly longer to progress- the animals act in the ways they would in real life (for example the elk are found commonly in herds of 15+ and stick together when traveling, the animals react to getting shot very realisticly too)CONS-The frame rate is a little low compared to what my pc should be getting ( i have a gtx 970, 3.5ghz 8 core processor, 16gb ram, 750 watt power supply and i get 50-80 fps on high)- It takes way too long to unlock new guns/equipment ( ive played 16 hours since release and ive only unlocked 1 new rifle after 80+ kills)-Their isnt as much veriety in antler variation as i would like (compared to classic atleast)- Its too easy to find large trophys, it should be more difficult to find the bigger trophys and smaller ones should be more common but instead its the other way around in this game- There are quite a bit of bugs as of now but they are putting out patches every day so its not a huge problemOver all i really have enjoyed the game and i would definitly recommend it to anyone who likes hunting or just wants a beautiful looking game to play. Sure its not perfect but its definitly worth the 29.99 and the devs are working hard on improving the game and are actually listening to the feedback they are getting. Cant wait to see what the future hold for this game!!!

This game is hard to run so make sure to do some research before you buy it to make sure you can run it. My system specs Rx 480 16gb ram AMD 8320 Windows 10

Posted: March 15
												10/10 would walk 500 miles through a forest shooting wildly at deer and such again.  But for real this is one of prettiest games I’ve ever played, amazing environment and probably the closest you’ll get to actually stalking animals through the wild...But a dirt bike, 4x4 or more quick travel spots would be a great addition to this game, takes so long to get anywhere and also the lack of human AIs makes for a strange experience after a while. Feels like hunting in a radiation exclusion zone.The menu system is also clunky and buggy but usable.Looking forward and hoping for DLC. (dinosaurs, mega fauna or) it would be a shame to see such a great looking game not taken further, hint hint.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												This game has met all my expectations and a little more even, yea it has bugs but the devs are working on fixes around the clock. first ill start off with the pros.PROS- Sound quality is extremly detailed and some of the best ive heard in any outdoor/hunting game (sounds just like real life imo)- The graphics are really good compared to classic- The environments and animals are incredibly detailed and super realistic- Animations look as life like as if you were actually watching a real deer- AI is decent although it could be better (for example the animals call way to often and ocasionally walk into trees and get stuck)- The missions are fun and keep you wanting to play more of them- The reserves are absolutely massive and it would definitly take a long time to have explored every inch of hunting area- One time purchase with no micro transactions whatsoever (A big improvement over TheHunter classic)- Leveling seems balanced although if you dont play some of the missions it will take significantly longer to progress- the animals act in the ways they would in real life (for example the elk are found commonly in herds of 15+ and stick together when traveling, the animals react to getting shot very realisticly too)CONS-The frame rate is a little low compared to what my pc should be getting ( i have a gtx 970, 3.5ghz 8 core processor, 16gb ram, 750 watt power supply and i get 50-80 fps on high)- It takes way too long to unlock new guns/equipment ( ive played 16 hours since release and ive only unlocked 1 new rifle after 80+ kills)-Their isnt as much veriety in antler variation as i would like (compared to classic atleast)- Its too easy to find large trophys, it should be more difficult to find the bigger trophys and smaller ones should be more common but instead its the other way around in this game- There are quite a bit of bugs as of now but they are putting out patches every day so its not a huge problemOver all i really have enjoyed the game and i would definitly recommend it to anyone who likes hunting or just wants a beautiful looking game to play. Sure its not perfect but its definitly worth the 29.99 and the devs are working hard on improving the game and are actually listening to the feedback they are getting. Cant wait to see what the future hold for this game!!!

content:
Posted: February 26
												habe das game jetzt ca. 4 stunden gespielt. nur im Multiplayer mit Freunden... leider musste ich feststellen das der Multiplayer nur für den Host "attraktiv" ist. Denn es ist nur dem Host möglich, die einzelnen Map-Punkte (u.a. "Aussenposten" "interessante Orte" und "Aussichtspunkte") zu erkunden. Die anderen Mitspieler können lediglich Jagen und dafür Punkte bekommen. Apro pos Punkte: Diese werden auch nur dann verteilt wenn man auf ein Tier geschossen hat, wenn dem nicht so ist, bekommt man rein gar nichts....Fazit:-) Multiplayer sollte ausgereift werden - alle Mitspieler sollten Waypoint aktivieren können.-) Gemeinsames Jagen sollte verbessert werden - Belohnungen beim Jagen sollten alle erhaltne, nicht nur wenn man draufgeschossen hat.-) Falldamage anpassen, da nicht realistisch. Man kann von einem Aussichtspunkt hinunter springen und man erleidet einen sehr geringen Schaden! Beim Springen auf eine Holzbank ist man tot. usw.-) Zielfernrohr ist manchmal verbuggt - das zoomen bei der Waffe funktioniert nicht korrekt, man sieht durch das Zielfernrorh und sieht dabei seine Hände und das Rohr ist extrem klein!-) Menü funktioniert nicht korrekt: Eine Auswahl ist manchmal nicht möglich, man muss 2-3 mal klicken.-) Muitionskauf: Man kann diese zwar kaufen, aber man sieht nicht wieviel Munition man gekauft hat. Nur wenn man aus dem Menü raus geht und die Waffe auswählt. Im "Lager" wird die Munition ebenfalls irgendwann angezeigt...-) Kein Zurück zum Haupt-Menü: Man muss andauernd das Spiel beenden und neustarten.-) usw. - ich hoffe die Entwickler sehen diesen Beitrag und werden diese Bugs ausbessern.... leider ist es mir nicht mehr möglich das Spiel zurückzugeben, sonst würde ich das auch machen!Für mich ist es eine Alpha-Versiojn und überhaupt nicht ausgereift! - Unbedingt Updates notwendig! - Keine Kaufempfehlung!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Product received for free
												The slow pace of hunting, the minimalistic UI, the sounds, and gorgeous graphics makes theHunter an impressively immersive experience that manages to be pretty relaxing and thrilling at the same time. The gameplay is in my short experience pretty simplistic, which is probably a necessity given that it's a pretty unique game. You find a trace, you follow it, you shoot the animal, everybody happy. It certainly has depth though, and the world feels very alive, despite pretty much just being you, the land, and the animals. I would attribute this to the AI of the animals combined with the mechanics of the world more than anything, as they'll pretty realistically react to noises, sightings, et cetera.My main gripes with the game seem to be things that will hopefully be improved upon in later patches. Namely, the tutorial is more or less just text boxes popping up every once in a while. Even though learning through playing might work, there's a good few mechanics that just aren't explained all that well and given how this isn't a common/mainstream type of game, a proper tutorial would really make it easier to get into the game.Secondly there's a slight lack of polish in some areas. Menus are a bit clunky and there are some smaller graphical bugs. The positional audio could use some work too, it would be an amazing asset to the immersion but there's just something off about it in terms of volume levels and direction.

content:
Posted: February 21
												Hello everyone! I really hope this review can help you wether buy the game or not, so lets get into it.theHunter: Call of the Wild has the potential to become the best and bigger hunting game in the market so far...I've been playing it for a while and I'm not dissapointed for the price.HOWEVER, there are still many small and medium bugs that need to be fixed in order to give the customer a proper game experience.How is that? I will explain it now.Some little bugs like sound glitches such as choppy rain effect when you are anywhere near a lake or river (10 meters or so) or the scope dissapearing for half a second when you shoot (only 2 out of 10 shots)The bugs that I'm more worried about is that the game GUI is completely unfriendly. I mean, I cannot change the mouse sensitivity since the mouse/keyboard does NOT have an "Apply" button, and when it comes to the loadout it's a little bit confusing or even sometimes the mouse click does not work anymore, so you have to close the thing and re-open it.Sometimes the animals will get stuck and will be an easy prey for you, or even dissapear (2 out of the 30 deers I've hunted so far had completely dissapeared, meaning that the tracks are entirely gone after a few miles of tracking, and it is kind of annoying)You will also have to invest many hours playing it, so if you are a busy person I recommend playing something less time demanding, since the game itself it is ment to be played slowly, no runnin n' gunnin' here mates.Now it has plenty of good things aswell...the atmosphere of the game its outstanding, the graphic its astounding, the lightning its well made, and the places are huges and not repetitive. You've got a story mode that kind of reminds me to "Firewatch", the voice acting it's really good, and if you are looking for a game to relax, give it a shot, it has been worth my time.Overall the game its pretty playable, and me being some kind of "lone ranger", I've enjoyed my time with it...I will come back later to make an update and answer questions of the people who are intending to buy it.Many thanks for reading and don't be afraid to ask.Peace!

content:
Posted: February 23
												TLDR:The game is playable and enjoyable but riddled with bugs so much so you might mistake this game for an early access rather than an actual game release. The gameplay itself is simple but even then the AI of the animals is lacking in so many ways with pathfinding issues. I'd say that in my 300 "harvests" of animals that around 1/3 of those were from "bugged animals" which were either standing still, running in place or stuck on the terrain. I didnt buy a hunting game only to be shooting fish in a barrel.Running the game on Max settings GTX 1080 i7-6500 3.4Ghz 16gig RAM rig runs the game perfectly, suffer from random audio crashes that have yet to be fixed despite many people suffering from it.Single player missions are a joke, often asking you to take a picture of a deer but the quest itself is bugged and no amount of pictures or the distance you are to the deer will make a difference. With the latest patch the developers essentially ripped away whatever progression system the game has, the idea is that you hunt animals and gain EXP, weapon experience and money. The developers have made it possible to essentially have end game gear within hours of playing by drastically reducing the amouint of experience needed to unlock these weapons (seriously i'd say they reduced the amount needed by about 80%). So now i have the end game weapons and can kill animals easily from an enormous distance so now what? I could go ahead and try and hunt the biggest trophies in the game for the bragging rights on the global leaderboards like in theHunter classic? WRONG. There is a leaderboards amongst your friend list but thats it and even then it isnt even working right now and doesnt update itself often.The game is nothing like a hunting game, if you think you are going to be sneaking up on groups of animals, picking out the biggest trophy and taking it down then think again! The game as it is punishes players who just hunt for trophies as far as progression is concerned. It's actually more beneficial for to kill every animal you see no matter what size or gender than going for a trophy, the difference in rewards between a trophy and a crappy female deer is tiny, maybe a third less money and EXP, the game doesnt even punish you for killing an animal with the wrong weapon nor does it punish you for failing to track a wounded animal down and finishing it off. so it gets to a point where you just shoot an animal and if you find that its barely wounded your better off just leaving it and finding some other animal to shoot at.If the developers want this game to last longer than a few months then they really need to make some major changes to this game, which is a shame because it could be a very good game once they fixed all the bugs and actually made it feel like you were hunting rather than playing some arcade shoot em up with deers instead of zombies.WIll change this review once game becomes more playable but if anyone is reading this right now please save your money for now, watch this game and keep an eye on its updates and maybe even catch it in a steam sale a few months down the line.

content:
Posted: February 19
												Game looks Great and Ive had a lot of fun so far. I like the progession where you get skill points and money to buy gear.Hate the hunter classic pay model and this is way better. They do need a rack/trophy system as it is now the racks seem to be all the same without any difference between animals or each side. Seems to me people arent giving it a chance.. low game time and then bad review. Try playing it for a while. It is not the same as the hunter classic but then again the hunter classic progressed over years so to expect this game to be the same is just not right. The new engine is WAY better then classic. You can spot animals further out and tracking is good. I like how the grass lays down where you and the animals walk and the wind and weather is cool. If you played the classic and liked spotting animals in the wide open grass field because the engine couldnt hadle it and then walk up and kill everything without a challenge then go pay to play classic. I find this one so much more realistic. harder to spot animals and they spook at a further range making you actually stalk and come up with  a plan. You have to look at your surroundings and realize the area your in may not be a good spot due to limited view or bushes. not everywhere is a good spot like classic. JMO If you have a decent computer then its good. Ive had a couple of crashes on start up but never in game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												This is a game in which changing from one map to another in singleplayer requires you to delete -ALL- character skills, leveling, bought items, discoveries. Essentially any and all progress made throughout God knows how many hours. This was 29 hours of unlocking that I need to do all over again. I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not. Why, Expansive Worlds, why? For as many good things can be said about Call of the Wild, something seems to have gone awfully wrong throughout development for it to have this sort of inexcusable disregard for basic functionality. Keep in mind that this is a game that features fairly complex stealth systems, somewhat complex animal AI, and so on, yet needs months worth of patches to get an "Exit to menu" button, which still hasn't been implemented, -in which debug menus show up for a split second when clicking on at least one of the buttons in the main menu, -in which animal call markers sometimes appear and sometimes not for no apparent reason, -in which there are no search filters, password protection or direct connecting in the server browser, -in which most menus are a pain to navigate due to poor design choices, -in which one ammunition stack always weighs the same regardless of its size, -in which there are red dot sights for shotguns mentioned in one of the skill menus despite the fact that there are no available red dot sights for shotguns and other discrepancies in the information provided to the player, -in which you can't buy more than 1 unit of ammunition at a time, -in which you can buy a seemingly infinite supply of the one ammo type that's free,-in which you can't interact with any of the unlockable hunting towers or land marks in a game you didn't host,-in which there at least weren't any animations for simultaneously walking and using animal calls the last time I checkedand yeah, I just discovered that unlike its predecessor your character info isn't tied into your account or anything, but into the singleplayer match you need to start the first time playing. And since there are two areas to choose from, you'd better host a multiplayer match if you want to play the other map because you otherwise need to wipe your only save slot, because why not? Keep in mind that it probably takes weeks or months of playing in order to unlock the later skills, perks, and equipment, so why does the save system work in such an awful way?Somehow, this is a recurring problem with Expansive World's games. There's always some insanely basic stuff that doesn't work or works in some astonishingly awkward ways that defies long-established conventions for no reason whatsoever. Having fun with this is task which currently demands a very high level of patience and tolerance for severely lacking functionality and polish, and I really, really don't understand how this trend can continue to persist within the games of a developer I'd think was experienced enough to make a keybinding menu that wouldn't completely break the control scheme if tampered with. This was fixed in an earlier patch, but yes, it was something that happened too. Call of the Wild is not a bad game if measured purely by its intended design, but this sort of garbage persisting is inexcusable and by now i feel pretty bad about supporting it in the first place.

There's always some insanely basic stuff that doesn't work or works in some astonishingly awkward ways that defies long-established conventions for no reason whatsoever. Having fun with this is task which currently demands a very high level of patience and tolerance for severely lacking functionality and polish, and I really, really don't understand how this trend can continue to persist within the games of a developer I'd think was experienced enough to make a keybinding menu that wouldn't completely break the control scheme if tampered with. This was fixed in an earlier patch, but yes, it was something that happened too. Call of the Wild is not a bad game if measured purely by its intended design, but this sort of garbage persisting is inexcusable and by now i feel pretty bad about supporting it in the first place.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9
												This game is something that I picked up as somewhat of an impulse buy, and for myself it is absolutely worth the money. Absolutely gorgeous visuals, provided you have the hardware to run it, and very nice audio work. I have had a lot of fun playing both on my own and multiplayer with friends. However, the game absolutely does have its issues, which honestly it shouldn't have been released with. Pros:-It is one of the more accurate hunting simulators out right now-Absolutely stunning scenery, water, animal animations, and lighting effects-The weapons are very satisfying, from the handling (which changes with different scopes, so a larger scope makes the weapon seem heavier) down to the meaty "thunk" of an arrow hitting its mark. All in all it does a much better job with the weapons than most FPSes do. -Very satisfying payoffs to effort put in. Making a difficult shot, finding a big bull elk after a long stalk, it's all fantastic.-Quick load times, for both single and multiplayer. The longest load times are generally when switching between reserves.-Very large maps with nice differences in terrain.Cons:-It is a slow paced game. Running generates a lot of noise and that scares the animals right off. -Depending on the map and location, you may go a long time without seeing an animal at all. Hirschfelden, in particular, seems almost desolate compared to the dense population of animals on Layton Lakes.-Unrealistic ballistics. If I shoot a deer in the shoulder within 20 meters, I don't care if it hit the shoulder blade first, I guarentee it would go through to the lung. Having a bullet stop short and ending up with a "Flesh Wound, bleed rate Very Low" is infuriating, especially when it seemed like an alright shot.-Bugs, so many bugs. So many, in fact, that I am going to detail them later, to avoid cluttering the cons list.-Not a whole lot of content, really. There are six trophy species on each reserve, and that's it. A LOT of content in theHunter Classic is not present in CotW.-Not well optimized. Even on more powerful rigs, if you're trying to play with settings maxed you're likely going to suffer some frame losses. Trying to play on a lower-end rig is not recommended. Some more detail on bugs that are present as of this review, as well as some older ones that seem to be fixed as I personally no longer experience them.-Frequent, inconsistent crashing. I sometimes go hours at a time without any issue, but the very next time I load up the game it crashes every five minutes. Very frustrating.-Animals in general are quite buggy on occasion, getting stuck on scenery, running in circles, standing completely still even when you approach, not being able to harvest an animal that is right in front of you, and likely some more issues I can't remember right now. -Walking uphill is incredibly frustrating, as it seems like your character is unable to pick up their feet more than six inches. It is also absurdly easy to slide down a slope on accident.-When fast-travelling to a location in multiplayer, if another player was standing in that location it would cause both players to die from, what seems to be, fall damage.-If an animal is harvested while photo mode is active, the cursor will not be visible and it is very hard to 'confirm' the kill to get back to hunting. -Sometimes tracks disappear into the abyss, which is incredibly frustrating when you've been on a trail for a long time.-Animals can spawn where they are not accessible. I made the mistake of shooting a few nice bull elk out on an island, where I could not walk out to as the water was too deep.-In multiplayer if another player uses a call, even if they are across the map, oftentimes the audio from the call can be heard as if you used the call yourself. Very startling to be stalking a deer and suddenly hear a distressed rabbit in your ear!Things in theHunter Classic that are not in CotW (that would be excellent additions)-Small game and bird hunting-Portable spawn points, like tents-Customizable blind and stand positions-Feeders-Trophy shot mode (Please, EW, put this in. I am so tired with not being able to get a nice trophy shot of a large buck because he died in a bush)-More variety. It would be very nice to have more species available, if not on these reserves than with added reserves.All in all, this game is a lot of fun, for me. I am alright with the sometimes-slow pace of it because of how stunning the visuals are, and it's a nice break from hectic life to play some hiking simulator. I love long-distance shooting in this game, and the weapons are incredibly satisfying. If your rig is lower end, I must warn you that somehow movement speed is connected to FPS and this will make it go from leisurely to an absolute drag. I have played other hunting games, and this is, despite its flaws, my favorite. I highly recommend watching videos on YouTube before purchasing to see if it's something that you'd be willing to put up with the flaws of. If it seems like a game you'd enjoy but the bug list is too long, I'd slap it on your wishlist and buy when it's on sale or just later in general, as it DOES seem like there are bug fixes going out decently often.All in all, Got stuck in a bush and died from fall damage, 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												I'm only about two hours into the game, but initial impressions are very positive.  The Good:Graphics are lovely, foliage density, lighting, weather--it's all on point.  I have brought my binoculars up multiple times checking if that movement in the distance is an animal, only to find a blowing branch or moving shadows. This really added to the immersiveness for me.  Branches and grass bend as you stalk past.  Playing the game with maxed settings (albeit at 1080p) with a constant 65fps, optimization seems solid, CPU/GPU temps both stayed well within reason.  intel i5 3.4GHz / gtx 980Sound is on point as well, highly directional, underbrush crunches, animals chirp, hoot, hollar and otherwise immerse you in the living environment.Core gameplay is solid.  Tracking, stalking, and shooting make for a fun formula.  I like that the hunting help (glowing tracks, directional assistance) are customizable, letting you play at the level of attention-to-detail you desire.  There seem to be plenty of progression options: weapon choices, different scopes, lures, binoculars; as well as a leveling skill/perk system.  And yet, the starting rifle feels plenty suitable for the game i've encountered thus far, so I don't feel rushed to level or worry about that stuff yet.The Bad:As some of the other reviews mentioned, the menu controls are kinda strange at times.  Either they occasionally hang so that you can't back out entirely, or there is some element of the selection that is somewhat tricky/unclear.  It hasn't caused me any major setbacks as a combination of escape and selecting the settings menu has allowed me to resume each time.  There don't seem to be many 'visual' character customization options.  Character presets  are pretty limited as are outfits.  This doesn't matter to me right now, but may become more important when I try out the multiplayer gameplay options.The To Be Continued:Haven't tried the multiplayer.  As that is the primary reason I was anticipating this game, I will have to update once I've had a chance to do so.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												Here is my opinion, after the first 10+ hours of the game.There should be no doubt that this game has great potential but currently lacks due to some bugs. Unfortunately, it's not something smallish and not so important stuff. Let me give an example. I have during my first few hours in the game already encountered numerous bugs where the animals are stuck in trees and rocks and keep running like they were on ecstacy, it might be fun to look at but after some time, you just get really annoyed about it. They might be easy to shoot - but they kill the overall feeling about being on a "real hunt". Another major flaw is the lack of greater depth in the multiplayer session. If you or your partner is the host of the server you play on, then it would be impossible for the other part to get certain spots on the map. Which again, unfortunately, sucks big time because of the distance between areas and places like "save zone/fast travel". They really need some kind of vehicle to reduce the distance to certain areas like this. Otherwise i think a lot of people would get tired of just walking/running from the other end of the map to another. Also I would like to see some more challenges online, not just those few they have right now, but something which could be a lot more interesting to do. Graphic wise, I think it look's really good. And the sounds are not bad at all. Small adjustments here and there would make this part of the game to be some of the best with The Hunter: Call of the Wild. Is it worth buying now? It depends on whether you are willing to invest in a product that possibly should have waited 2-3 months longer to correct some crucial bugs as the game crashes from time to time. (Something the dev's are working on right now). Even though this review seems negative, I just can't get myself to press the "negative" button. I think if some of those things i have written is going to change, then this game can get really good over time! At least im exicited to see what the future brings, hopefully more animals, new areas, easier level system, and vehicles.

content:
Posted: February 18
												This game is a big step up from the theHunter Classic. First off you only need to pay once for the game, no other fees. Graphics are amazing, lots of details with the grass, water, and other things. Sounds are pretty on point and the timing of where you are and the noise level are pretty amazing. You still have a hunter score or leveling system(whatever you call it).This game also has some bad traits but, nothing that should turn away a person from playing this amazing game. Optimizing needs some work. I have an ok gaming pc, for example I can play Gta 5 online on high settings and do about 60 - 80 fps. This game I can only run on low settings and get about 20 - 35 fps. Animals do get stuck sometimes like on rocks on the side of a hill which gives the player a huge chance at getting the animals. The good news is all the downsides are pretty simple changes if they decide to do them. Another con is that when you shoot the weapon with the scope on, it will glitch out and you will have to re-aim which means if you got a bad shot on the animal then your probly gonna be tracking it for a while unless your fast and re-aiming and shooting the target. I still recommend the game because the experience is like no other game out there. Animal movements are pretty realistic and cool to see in a game. For $30 I recommend this game and this game just released, so many changes are going to happen. Keep that in mind!

												Coming from somebody who plays a lot of open world video games, and has spent many hours in the wilderness, this game is super A+ #1 awesome.Honestly, a few bugs and glitches here and there, but nothing game breaking and honestly is barely took away from my overall experience. This is a game I will play for hours on end and not even know time is passing.Pros: -amazing environmental graphics and sounds (Trees/overall fauna is unbelievable)- Animal AI (needs just a little tuning but otherwise captivating)- Weapon physics/bullet penetration/animal penetration- Choice in weapons/ammo- Map size and scale, super realistic- Story mode and quests!!- Real sense of progression with skill and perk leveling systemsThings they need to improve:-Effectiveness of calls/scents are too high, they don't work that well in real life-Animal pathfinding/sticking on objects-UI needs to be smoother in the shop-Needs a buck point system-Prone positioning while on uneven terrain is super clippy. All in all, they can have this game vastly improved and damn near perfect with a few key patches. I recommend getting the game NOW, because it's very playable and immersive even with these minor issues, and by the time they have the game perfect you can have a leveled up character ;-)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19
												So add my review onto the pile of negatives. I see most of the positive reviews seem to be in direct response to the negative reviews and the which weigh in heavily on the Buggyness of the game in its released state. And most of those positive reviews are basing their positivity on the assumption that all bugs present will be fixed. I can say for sure that this is usually not the case, especially for a game released in full. They already have peoples money, they cashed in on the product. so even if they did want to polish it. They have little tangiable return guarantee to do so. Everyone should review a game (especially a full release) in its current state, not for what is planned or what could possibly be fixed later, because those are NEVER guarantees.This is my first hunting game, I played a couple hours of thehunter: classic as soon as I got to the microtransaction part (I like to play games, not money syphoning tubes). The first 6 hours of playing this game was fantastic. I completely forgot I was in my room on a computer. 100% immersion. Then, I found a bear. Bears are completely unfunctional. its as if they put the bear model, its sounds and 2 animations into the game a week before release. Half of the pause menu doesnt work with keyboard controls or any of the button prompts displayed on the bottom of the menu, This is something you fix in the first few weeks of development. I returned today into my game to do more hunting and found that none of the tracking indicators were workint, not even the direction cone when you identify a track. I had messed around with the tracking settings in my previous play session but that was to turn them back on. Sure enough, they were all on. I switched them of and on and this changed nothing, I restart my computer and this changed nothing. so one of the core mechanics of the gameplay is now bugged and my next step is to validate my game files which I will update when I do. This game is beautiful and runs well on my computer (gtx 1080 I7 6700)For those who want a good disconnect from life and a trip through the wilderness, $30 is quite modest. But expect to encounter sub alpha levels of bug fodder. And for a dev team who has a history in this genre, Its a bit sad to see.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Keep in mind i really enjoy this game. But i'll say you shouldn't buy it due to the current state it is in. (not everyone can accept some of the game breaking bugs)Graphics and atomosphere are top notch in the game. You can easily get immersed due to the great sounds,lighting,and overall graphicsThe gameplay itself is pretty straight forward, you have a quest or two you can do if you want but overall you're just hunting which is great.Multiplayer is a mess, if the animals are not teleporting everywhere or invulnerable, they are running into trees and rocks and getting stuck ruining the fun of hunting. Many times you cant even harvest the animals you've killed.There are many gamebreaking bugs at the moment which leave me dumbfounded. Some of these bugs that i encounter all the time are        - Rifle scopes not working if you also have used a bow        - Waypoints have either not worked at all or will show you two places at once on your UI/HUD (lots of times both of them aren't even the spots you picked), also you can't delete them so you have to reload to get rid of them        - Tracking is pretty broken in many ways (leading you the wrong way, sometimes in a circle)        - Hit reg is really janky since the new update (double lung shots sometimes give minor wounds? wtf)        - Multiplayer is a mess Overall i love the game but I will never tell anyone to buy it due to the state the game was released in (patches have made it worse so far)

content:
Posted: March 30
												Wow, 80 hours already. I think this is also my first Steam review.I enjoy theHunter COTW. At the core it is a hunting simulator, and in that regard it performs somewhat admirably. The landscapes in both playable maps are expansive and beautiful. The game engine really brings out the beauty of these hunting grounds whether it's a clear summer day or moonlit foggy night. Seeing the jagged antlers of the buck you've been intently tracking for what seems like hours shimmer in the sun while it trots within the tall foliage is quite the sight to see. The sun's rays sometimes glow through the trees, creating an ambience that causes you to stop and just take it all in. Through numerous patches that have come after the game's release, the game is in, at least for me, a playable state. As mentioned in many other reviews perhaps these bugs should have been ironed out before release. I won't get into that debate as it seems to be the industry-wide norm. Bugs are minimal now, animal pathing and AI seems to be working more reliabely (though with some major faults, such as herd behavior). I haven't spontaneously combusted by walking between two rocks or two saplings in a long time. Sure, there's still some issues with terrain and how the player/animals interact with it, buggy/misplaced things such as grass hanging in the air, etc. With a map this expansive there are bound to be some issues and animals will eventually get stuck. This is part of the process and is something I can live with. However, due to my aforementioned herd behavior mention, if an animal as part of a herd does manage to bug out on a rock and get stuck, the rest of the animals will circle voilently around it until it dies (or you get trampled). This can lead to some funny/fruitful opportunities but as a hunting simulator it greatly detracts from the immersion. Multiplayer is bare bones minimal. The single-player questing system is absent in the multiplayer version, instead replaced with competitions you can start with other players. These include hitting an animal in the heart first, bagging 3 fallow deer trophies, etc. While it can be a worthy distraction it would have been nice to be able to quest with other players. Especially with those difficult missions (high level photos, gold star ratings, etc.). There remains the issue of connected players to a host server being unable to unlock new landmarks/outposts, etc. I personally never join a server if I play multiplayer as I always want the option, so I host. It explains why there are so many servers with just 1 player in them.My issue is that this developer seems to be following the trend. A console release has been announced recently and with the lack of updates it will only get worse in my opinion. A guise of two separate console and PC development teams is their only defense - just take a look at the patch note comments. The sad truth is that development for the PC version will slow until they get their cash flow from the console release. The game takes a modestly beefy PC to render the graphics at their ultimate potential, and a lot of people don't have the pcmasterrace in them.  If they get a console version that runs at 30 FPS and has full game pad support, a lot of people might hop on that boat. Why wouldn't they release a console version? Lotta money potential. And that seems to be their game - hey, it's a business. TLDR - Console development is a money maker. PC development will likely slow. I enjoy the game, but I can't support the business model as a consumer. I understand it though. Try getting the game when it's on sale. Or, you know... Eat a citrus fruit so you don't get scurvy, matey... 6.5/10

content:
Posted: February 16
												Really good game WITHOUT micro transaction or PAY to hunt everything.ALSO there are as far as i notised no serious bugs or problems, and the game do not feel unfinished or like a Beta like many "unserious reviews claim".I think that many of the reviews sound kind of fake and are negative on purpose.( im so glad they desided to release "the hunter" game with one payment only, since the pay for this and that scared med away from the previous title "the hunter".ANyway im not expert in the past game the hunter, and i only played the new "call of the wild" for 2 houres.But so far i enjoy it and the changes.The game world is beautifull and there are many cool features such as the plants moving when a small animal sneak arround.The sound is really amazing and create a good atmosphere and will make you feel releaxed.THe game have a career/skill/perk system wich will allow you to upgrade different things over time such as tracking animals and shooting ect.I think this is nice, since you start as a rookie hunter and become better and better.I am not aware if you can start as a "pro" hunter with all perks and all guns as a kind of free world go hunting kind of thing, but the career thing i like so for me no issue.When it come to animals you can hunt there are like 8-10 big animals such as "black bear, red tail, mose, fox, wild boar and other animals. And you dont have to pay to hunt them :-)Everytime you hunt down an animal you get awarded xp and money.The ingame money you earn can be used to buy new weapons, bullets and sometimes you even come across small buildings you can buy and use for hunting.The tracking of animals is like in the hunter, but i think it is a little more easy to see the tracks now.I think you can be hardcore and adjust the kind of help you like and how visual things will be.You can either go hunting on your own or with friends, and you also get  missions you can do, example hunt an animal and make a photo of it ( press p ).It effect the game how much you hunt in an area, and you can view this on your map as a purple colour, so try to not shoot everything you see, and do some different hunts all over the map.So far the only bug i found during 2 hour gameplay is that i fall down a mountain, and 5 minutes later I could not use any of my gear. But other than that, no big bugs that i notised.It run very good and smooth though the game world is huge and very detailed.Can i recommend this game.. YES i think it is really good, and I hope that they release some cheap dlc's in the future so people who like more animals or gear can buy example an weapon pack or animal pack.Ps. if you buy and do not like the game, then you can ask for a refund if you use the steam support system and play less than 2 houres.. So what do you have  to loose by giving it a try ;-)

content:
Posted: March 23
This game is a Hunter Simulator set in european deciduous forests, made by Expansive Worlds, a quite experienced hunter-sim developer underpined by Avalanche Studios and their really astonishing APEX Engine. Multiplayer included.  Aspect Annotation   Graphics, Atmosphere and Scenery:☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺OO  The new APEX engine is definetely meritorious, it offers some great visual feedback for the player: Wind Simulation, Falling Leaves, Curving Grass and Decent Texture&Draw Distance. Eveverything in the games looks real enough for the player to relish it.   Gameplay:☺☺☺☺☺☺OOOO It's kinda meh. The whole gameplay spins around following the trails of animals and then shooting them dead with deficient variativity. It's a notably protracted and tedious process, especially in late game. The Character is also really flaccid, and there are no vehicles in this game, and that convicts the player to spend half of his time walking from point A to point B on a really big map with the lack of fast travel spots. Multiplayer mode makes it much pleasant and fun though, but it still won't last for long.   Stability and Online:☺☺☺☺☺OOOOO It's really poor. There are lots of gamebreaking bugs and gliches from disappearing corpses to critical error crashes. Same applies to the multiplayer, where crashes and disconnects are a comming thing  Overall: 7.1/10 While TheHunter:CotW ensures some fascinating immersion and visual fidelity, the amount of systematic problems and a considerably wearisome gameplay mechanics might dramatically spoil the impression of the game

content:
Posted: March 26
												Ok not going to rehash all the other great reviews out there already but as of this time I have 82 hours in it and i havent even made it to the second reserve . I dont know how some of you justify bang for the buck but with that much game play in half the game its pretty hard to ♥♥♥♥♥ even with the glitches which are certainly better than when released and being worked on all the time. If you like hunting games bingo its a winner if you like walking simulators also spot on. The rare few who actually like both its about as good as it gets in that sense ,plus a level grind aspect that keeps me playing with a goal to achieve . The glitches mentioned before while annoying are not game breaking the disappearing tracks issue is the hardest to deal with but also getting better (my suggestion is to be dam sure before you let that arrow or bullet fly). I like many others have literaly spent hours tracking a less that stellar shot to make sure i keep my consecutive harvest bonus going and it just seems wrong even in the game world to just take pot shots at everything then let them die slowly out in the brush to rot. I find if i just pick an undiscovered spot on the map and walk ( not run sometimes even in stealth which seems agonozingly slow) there I will several chances to track seomthing or even straight out walk up on a clean shot situation.I dont find the hunting blinds all that helpful but they do work you just have to use the calls but it seems boring when there is plenty to hunt walking around. Running is only a means to get from point a to b not a method to travel and expect to hun. The wildlife will hear you before you even get a warning call from them and its like your on a deserted planet. If your a twitch pvp gotta shoot a hundered rounds an hour player keep walking this isnt your game. There is however plenty of beautiful scenery and simply walking to open up map areas is enjoyable if you have a 5.1 or better headset or surround system crank it up and head into the woods listen for warning and mating calls and stealth towards them its very cool. Keep in mind which way your scent is going as it will tip them off before anything else does many times. I love the direction this game is going and cant wait to visit the other reserve looking forward to some new reserve dlcs maybe a few more things to hunt would rock but still pretty darn good now. I would like the option to start a second data or more so as i go to a new reserve i can start from scratch while still having the option to bring my developed character to look for bigger game as well . I love the level asect of it for me i like to have a goal to work towards there is a good mix of xp grind and  money grind here to keep you motiviated. They cant give it all to you for free at the start or you'd get bored quickly. I do feel like having to start over from scratch on the consecutive harvest thing is a bit of a pain but not horrible. I mostly find it makes it impossible to jump in and play for short bursts because so much of the game requires you to get gold kills and that is ony going to happen if you have 100% modifier on consecutive harvest as well as quick kill and it needs to be basically mythical grade animal.Graphics are really nice sometimes i just climb a mountain to see the view from up there some of the waters edge shots you get as well looking out over a tranquil mountiain lake or river is beautiful. Dont judge it by all the negative reviews while the points are valid a lot of times, many have been addressed and i have found none game breaking aggravating at times yes but not gamebreaking. I have only had one or two animals that i got any sort of decent shot into that didnt result in a successful harvest with diligent tracking and patience.Almost forgot dont forget to try the bow I started this game thinking good lord I'll never get close enough to anything to kill it with a bow but you will and its a real sense of accomplishment when you take down a mythical level red deer lets say with your bow very cool. I hunt almost exclusively with it now but still break out the 270 as well ,sometimes you just want to make sure especially if your on a mission and have 100% harvest bonus and dont want to risk it.There it is all i can think of hope it helps i enjoyed this game enough that i didnt even mind buying it full price 30 bucks is not outrageous . I looked at the classic version and I would never enjoy it as much as this one even with the larger number of things to hunt micro transaction games just leave me with a bad vibe and the days of monthy subscription games are pretty much done. Thnx hopefully this isnt too gramaticaly borked a nice spell checker gramar checker would be handy here lol.

content:
Posted: February 19
												For the few hours I have played CotW I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hunting game and doesn't want to pay extra for Classic.For people new to the franchise, I would start with CotW. It is the cheaper alternative and delivers for its price range. While Classic may have more animals, gameplay and community features CotW is a more inclusive system. Not nessecarily easier as it comes with its own challenges but the learning curve is more user-friendly.For people returning from previous theHunter games I believe it would depend on what you want. In a way, CotW is closer to Primal than Classic. There are fewer animals, less trophy diversity and fewer game mechanics but the AI is more advanced and the species don't feel like the same system tacked onto multiple different models.As for bugs I have only experienced one major one that simply required a game restart. There are several smaller ones that are more annoyances than game breaking, which I am sure will be patched out in the following weeks.As for the things I don't like, coming from Classic was a bit of a shock and while I know some people would be upset for the change, EW was very upfront that CotW would not be what Classic is. It was sold as a game that would not compete with Classic and some people seem to have forgotten that, or never understood what that ment. After a few hours of playing I grew to enjoy what CotW offers at this moment in time, however, it does feel rather empty. Such large maps with so little diversity.Despite this, I do think this game is worth buying. Be it now, or in a few months. If you are worried about bugs and missing features I would wait but definitely come back every once in awhile to see how the game progresses.Good luck and happy hunting!
